Natural asphalt, which is believed to have been formed during an early stage in the breakdown of organic marine deposits into petroleum, characteristically contains minerals, while residual petroleum asphalt does not. Asphalt has been used since the 3rd millennium BCE for waterproofing; it is also used for road paving, roof coating, joint sealing, and a waterproof barrier in sandy soils. Ancient sources for asphalt were Egypt, the north end of the Dead Sea, the Is river northwest of Babylon, and the Greek island of Zante.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: asfalt
asphalt (bituminous material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Asphalt mixture of 13-60 percent bitumens with finely pulverized mineral fillers, usually limestone. It differs from natural asphalt by the presence of paraffin and a greater content of petroleum oils.
Een term die wordt gebruikt voor het bitumineuze afval van steenkooldestillatie, dat machinaal wordt vermengd met zand of kalksteen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: artificial asphalt
kunstmatig asfalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Asphalt obtained from the refining of petroleum; the heavier or more viscous portions of certain crude oils are asphalts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: petroleum asfalt
petroleum asphalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemeen te gebruiken voor een aantal natuurlijke ontvlambare stoffen die rijk zijn aan koolstof en waterstof.

Any of various solid or semisolid mixtures of hydrocarbons that occur in nature or that are obtained as residues from the distillation of petroleum or coal. For the blackish hydrocarbon portion of asphalt, use "asphaltic bitumen."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bitumen
bitumen (materiaal)
bitumen (material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A variety of natural asphalt having a black color, brilliant luster, brittle consistency, and conchoidal fractures. It is found only in the Uinta Mountains of Utah. The term "gilsonite" was originally a registered trademark in the late 19th century. It is used in black varnishes, lacquers, baking enamels, japans, linoleum, floor tile, and paving where it increases resistance to acids, alkalis, and water. In the early 19th century, gilsonite was often mixed with mica, asbestos, gums, or resins to produce electrical components. It is also the first solid hydrocarbon to be converted to gasoline.
Een natuurlijke asfaltvarieteit met een zwarte kleur, een heldere glans en een bruine zweem; vertoont een conchoïdaal breukvlak.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gilsoniet
gilsonite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Natural asphalt that is collected in pits or lakes, often a rather elastic variety of asphalt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lake asphalt
lake asphalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Asfaltsoorten die zijn vermengd met meer dan 10% mineralen.
Porous rock such as sandstone or limestone that has become impregnated with natural asphalt through a geological process, so that the asphalt has more than 10% minerals.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rock asphalt
steenslagasfalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An emulsion of asphalt cement and water, that contains a small amount of emulsifying agent. The amount of asphalt in emulsion will depend upon the grade and type, but is typically 55-65% by volume. Uses include surfacing floors, painting pipes, and waterproofing concrete walls.
Een asfaltemulsie in wateroplossing; wordt onder meer gebruikt voor vloerbedekking, het verven van buizen en het waterdicht maken van betonnen muren.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: emulsie-asfalt
emulsified asphalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een donkerbruin tot zwart plakkerig residu dat voornamelijk ontstaat bij de zuivering van ruwe olie; wordt gebruikt als het bindmiddel in asfaltbeton.
Natural or modified asphalt or an asphalt aggregate intended for use as a binder in asphalt concrete.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: paving asphalt
wegenasfalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Cutback asphalt composed of asphalt cement and a naptha or gasoline-type diluent of high volatility, which evaporated rapidly.
Vloeibaar asfalt dat is samengesteld uit asfaltcement met een nafta- of benzineachtig oplosmiddel met een hoge vluchtigheid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rapid-curing asphalt
snelhardend asfalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Cutback asphalt composed of asphalt cement and oils of low volatility and slow evaporation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: langzaamhardend asfalt
slow-curing asphalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een dik, stroperig, bruinachtig tot zwart asfaltresidu dat ontstaat door de gedeeltelijke verdamping of destillatie van petroleum of andere koolwaterstoffen op asfaltbasis of van hout; de samenstelling ervan varieert.

Thick, viscous, brown or black, inflammable liquid residue resulting from the partial evaporation or distillation of wood (such as pine, fir, or larch), sugar, tobacco, peat, coal, or other organic substance. It contains hydrocarbons, resins, alcohols, and other compounds; it has a heavy resinous or bituminous odor. It is used as an antiseptic, for coating asphalt roads, preserving timber, caulk on wooden sailing ships, waterproofing for roofing papers, insecticide, in disinfectant soaps. Some tars, such as those obtained from pine or beech wood, have been mixed with linseed oil to form a dark brown glaze and for other purposes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tar (material)
teer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Black viscous liquid with a naphthalene odor obtained by the distillation of bituminous coal. It can be separated into several fractions: gasoline, oil, creosote, and pitch. Coal tar is used in the manufacture of plastics, aniline dyes, for waterproofing, paints, roofing, roads, and as a pesticide.
Een product van de afbrekende destillatie van steenkool.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: coal tar
koolteer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Tar obtained by the destructive distillation of wood; used as a preservative.
Teer verkregen door de afbrekende destillatie van hout; wordt gebruikt als een conserveringsmiddel.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: houtteer
wood tar

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood tar produced by distilling pine wood, used in wood preservatives and medicinal products.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pijnteer
pine tar

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Substance obtained by melting rosin with pine tar.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: navy pitch
navy pitch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Complex mixture of hydrocarbons that occurs naturally beneath the earth's surface, viscous yellow to black in color. Petroleum is refined (i.e.,separated by distillation) into useable fractions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: petroleum
petroleum

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless, liquid hydrocarbon obtained in the fractional distillation of petroleum which is used chiefly as a motor fuel but also as a solvent.
Een kleurloze, vloeibare koolwaterstof, verkregen bij de gefractioneerde destillatie van aardolie; wordt voornamelijk gebruikt als motorbrandstof maar ook als oplosmiddel.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: benzine
gasoline

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Compressed gas that consists of flammable hydrocarbons such as propane and butane, and is used especially as fuel or as raw material for chemical synthesis.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: liquefied petroleum gas
vloeibaar petroleumgas

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A four carbon saturated alkane hydrocarbon that occurs naturally in petroleum. It is used in high performance liquid fuels for household and industrial purposes, as a propellant in aerosols, and as a raw material for synthetic polymers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: butaan
butane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of three types of isometric paraffin hydrocarbon found in petroleum and natural gas.
Elk van drie soorten isometrische alkaankoolwaterstof die voorkomen in aardolie en aardgas.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pentaan
pentane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Liquefied petroleum gas, marketed under pressure in steel cylinders as bottled gas; used especially in cook stoves.
Vloeibaar aardgas dat onder druk wordt verkocht in stalen cylinders als flessengas; wordt voornamelijk gebruikt voor kookfornuizen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: propaan
propane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A chemical compound obtained or derived industrially from petroleum or natural gas.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: petrochemical
petrochemisch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A soft, greasy, translucent, semi-solid mixture of hydrocarbons, obtained from petroleum and used as an ointment and lubricant.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: petrolatum
petroleum jelly

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: De witte hars van de Cinnamomum camphora, die wordt gebruikt voor het verharden van nitrocellulose plastic en in geneesmiddelen, desinfecterende middelen en explosieven.
The white resin of the species Cinnamomum camphora, used for hardening nitrocellulose plastic. Camphor is also in pharmaceuticals, disinfectants, and explosives.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: camphor (resin)
kamfer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless gas (CO2) with a sharp odor; it is a minor component in the earth's atmosphere, does not support combustion, dissolves in water to form carbonic acid, is formed in animal respiration and in the decay or combustion of animal and vegetable matter, and is absorbed from the air by plants in photosynthesis. Carbon dioxide is used as a refrigerant and is found in carbonated beverages and fire extinguishers, among other uses.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: carbon dioxide
koolstofdioxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An odorless, colorless, tasteless, and highly poisonous gas produced by the incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials. It is used in organic synthesis and metallurgy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: carbon monoxide
koolstofmonoxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A flammable, colorless gas with a strong, suffocating odor; first synthesized in 1859, but it occurs naturally in coal and wood smoke, as an outdoor air pollutant in large cities, and found in indoor environments from items such as new particle board, freshly laid carpet, foam, adhesives, insulation, and new fabrics. Formaldehyde is a powerful reducing agent reacts with many materials on contact.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: formaldehyde
formaldehyde
formaline

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Te gebruiken voor een stroperige, melkachtige vloeistof bestaande uit hars of was in de vorm van zeer kleine druppels in waterige suspensie, die wordt verkregen van rubberbomen; gebruikt voor vele rubbertoepassingen, zoals hechtmiddel. Ook te gebruiken voor een waterige dispersie van synthetisch rubber en van rubberachtig plastic.

Viscous, milk-like fluid composed of resin or wax in the form of tiny globules in aqueous suspension, obtained especially from rubber trees; used for many rubber applications, such as adhesive. Use also for a water dispersion of synthetic rubber and of rubberlike plastic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: latex
latex (organic material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of the large group of fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and triglycerides that occur in living organisms and are characteristically soluble in certain organic solvents but only partially soluble in water; they are oily to the touch. With carbohydrates and proteins, lipids are one of three types of materials that compose living cells. The structure of lipids range from simple straight chain hydrocarbon to complex ring structures. They can be subdivided as 1) fatty acids, 2) neutral fats, 3) phospholipids, 4) glycolipids, 5) aliphatic alcohols and waxes, 6) terpenes, and 7) steroids. Any of the large group of fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and triglycerides that occur in living organisms and are characteristically soluble in certain organic solvents but only partially soluble in water; they are oily to the touch. With carbohydrates and proteins, lipids are one of three types of materials that compose living cells. The structure of lipids range from simple straight chain hydrocarbon to complex ring structures. They can be subdivided as 1) fatty acids, 2) neutral fats, 3) phospholipids, 4) glycolipids, 5) aliphatic alcohols and waxes, 6) terpenes, and 7) steroids.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lipid
lipide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An ester of a long-chain fatty acid (such as stearic acid or palmitic acid), of plant or animal origin, that is that is nonvolatile, insoluble in water, oily or greasy to the touch, and solid at room temperature. Chemically, fats are identical to animal and vegetable oils, consisting primarily of glycerides, which are esters formed by the reaction of three molecules of fatty acids with one molecule of glycerol. Pure fats are colorless, odorless, tasteless and will float on water. Examples of natural fats are butter, lard and tallow. Fats may be hydrolyzed with an alkali to form soap in a process called saponification. Fats are also used in leather tannage, paints, and protective coatings. An ester of a long-chain fatty acid (such as stearic acid or palmitic acid), of plant or animal origin, that is that is nonvolatile, insoluble in water, oily or greasy to the touch, and solid at room temperature. Chemically, fats are identical to animal and vegetable oils, consisting primarily of glycerides, which are esters formed by the reaction of three molecules of fatty acids with one molecule of glycerol. Pure fats are colorless, odorless, tasteless and will float on water. Examples of natural fats are butter, lard and tallow. Fats may be hydrolyzed with an alkali to form soap in a process called saponification. Fats are also used in leather tannage, paints, and protective coatings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fat
vet
vet (fat)
vetten

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A viscous oily liquid that is found in certain animal and vegetable matter. Lecithins are composed of a mixture of diglycerides of fatty acids (stearic, palmitic, oleic, linolenic and linoleic) linked to the choline ester of phosphoric acid. Commercially, lecithin is obtained from soybean, corn, and egg yolk. It is used for emulsifying, dispersing, and wetting, added to food products, paints, printing inks, plastic molding as a release agent, textiles as a lubricant, and leather as a dressing.

Een vetachtige substantie die voorkomt in eidooiers en andere dierlijke en plantaardige stoffen; wordt onder andere gebruikt als een emulgator in caseïneverf en om de viscositeit van drukinkt te reguleren.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lecithin
lecithine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to a variety of dense, permanent pigments that produce a wide variety of red shades ranging from light, bright red to a deep purplish red. Pigments can be natural, earth pigments (hematite, Indian red, Venetian red) or synthetically prepared pigments (light red). All iron oxide reds are stable, permanent pigments with good tinting strength and are the primary colorant in ochers and siennas. The pigment was first manufactured in the early 18th century. Today it is often a furnace product made from steel-mill waste.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ijzeroxiderood
iron oxide red (pigment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A bright, clear red iron oxide earth pigment that has since been replaced by light red.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gulf red
gulf red

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A bright, natural red volcanic pigment originally mined at Pozzuoli near Naples, Italy. It was used by the Romans and others as a paint pigment, becoming popular for fresco paintings because it dried quickly to a hard impenetrable surface like cement.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Pozzuoli red (pigment)
Pozzuoli rood

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Reddish pigment made of a fine, soft, natural red clay.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: red bole
roodachtig bruin
roodachtig bruin (materiaal)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Earth color made from clay or by calcining selected grades of yellow ocher. This type is sometimes called burnt ocher.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: red ocher (pigment)
rode oker
rode oker (pigment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to red iron oxide or a similar pigment, particularly when it is a component of reddish-brown chalk or mixed with lime and water and applied with a brush to create underdrawings for frescoes. These underdrawings are called "sinopie."

Verwijst naar rood ijzeroxide of een soortgelijk pigment, in het bijzonder wanneer het een bestanddeel is van roodbruin krijt, of is vermengd met kalk en water en is aangebracht met een penseel om ondertekeningen te maken voor fresco's. Deze ondertekeningen worden sinopia's genoemd.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sinopia
sinopia (pigment)
sinopia (pigment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An earth pigment containing red iron oxide, originally obtained from Spain. It is a coarse grain, an inexpensive colorant, having a dull red color, and used in industrial paints.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Spanish red oxide
Spanish red oxide (pigment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A bright red pigment prepared by depositing an organic red dye, such as alizarin, on a red iron oxide base.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Tuscan red
toscaans rood

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An orange-red mineral, found as soft lumps consisting of arsenic disulfide, having a resinous luster; it is found in eastern Europe, Asia, and western North America in lead and silver ores along with orpiment (arsenic trisulfide). Realgar was once widely used as a pigment because of its bright rich color in works from China, India, Central Asia, Egypt, and Europe. However, it is extremely toxic, not stable, and can deteriorate badly in oil paint films.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: realgar
realgar (pigment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pigment bestaande uit kwiksulfiet, zowel het natuurlijke mineraal cinnaber als de kunstmatige verbinding.

Synthetic pigment composed of red mercuric sulfide, chemically the same as the natural mineral cinnabar. There are two methods for preparing vermilion, a dry-process and a wet-process. The dry-process method, adding mercury to molten sulfur, was invented by the Chinese then imported to Europe ca. 8th century, seemingly via the Islamic world. The wet-process method, placing the ground black mercuric sulfide isomorph into a solution of ammonium sulfide or potassium sulfide, was developed in the late 17th century in Germany. Vermilion is a dense pigment with excellent hiding power, used in oil, watercolor, egg tempera, and fresco paintings. When exposed to ultraviolet light and oxygen, or chloride ions, vermilion can change from its normal red crystalline form to gray or black, resulting in dark discolorations.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vermilion (pigment)
vermiljoen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Obsolete permanent pigment made of antimony trisulfide. Invented and patented by Murdock in Scotland in 1847, it was replaced by cadmium red in the 1920s.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: antimony vermilion
antimoon vermiljoen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Type of dry-process vermilion pigment originally made in China.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Chinees vermiljoen
Chinese vermilion

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Type of wet-process vermilion, originally made in England.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Engels vermiljoen
English vermilion

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A term sometimes applied to the more yellowish kinds of vermilion.
Een term die soms gebruikt wordt voor de gelere soorten vermiljoen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: orange vermilion (pigment)
oranje vermiljoen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: De blauwige - of minst gelige - variant van vermiljoen.
The bluish, or least yellowish, variety of vermilion.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: scarlet vermilion (pigment)
scharlaken vermiljoen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Heavy, opaque, orange-red pigment composed of lead tetroxide. Although chemically equivalent to the mineral minium, red lead pigment has been synthetically prepared by roasting lead white (480 C) since before the 5th century BCE. Red lead has been found as a pigment on early objects from Egypt, China, Japan, India, Persia, and Rome; it is no longer used as an artist's color because is has poor light stability and poor working properties, although it is still used to color glass and ceramic glazes. Pliny called it "secondarium minium." It was widely used in illuminated manuscripts, and with its use, the term "miniare" came to mean "to color with red lead," giving rise to the term "miniature." Red lead paint was used as an anticorrosion primer for structural iron and steel until the late 20th century.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: red lead (pigment)
rood lood

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The most common barium mineral, barium sulfate (BaSO4), occurring in hydrothermal ore veins containing lead and silver, in sedimentary rocks such as limestone, in clay deposits formed by the weathering of limestone, in marine deposits, and in cavities in igneous rock in Spain, Germany, and in the southern Appalachian, central states, and California in the United States. It commonly forms as large tubular crystals, as rosettelike aggregates of those crystals, or as divergent plates known as crested barite. It is abundant. Ground barite is used in oil and gas well drilling muds, in the preparation of barium compounds, as a body or filler for paper, cloth, and phonograph records, as a base for white pigment, and as an inert body in colored paints.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: barite
bariumsulfaat

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Finely ground pigment made from pumice vocanic stone, used to make a clear glaze for ceramics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: puimsteen
puimsteen (wit pigment)
pumice (pigment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A crystalline form of lead monoxide, the oxidized product of molten lead that has been stirred or atomized to incorporate air then cooled and ground to form the yellow powder. It is used as a drier in paint and varnish, for the fluxing of earthenware, and in the manufacture of glass. Litharge tends to be slightly more orange than massicot, another crystalline form of lead monoxide, due to the presence of small amounts of red lead oxide.

Monoxide van lood dat van nature voorkomt als rood kristal of wordt verkregen in oranje vlokken of poeder door processen die worden uitgevoerd bij temperaturen die boven het smeltpunt liggen; wordt vooral gebruikt als een droogmiddel in verf en vernis, als vloeimiddel bij aardewerk, en in de glasproductie.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: litharge
loodglit
loodoranje

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aarde die silica en alumina en ijzeroxides bevat; bevat vaak verbindingen van barium of calcium. Komt voor in geelachtige, bruine of roodachtige kleuren. Wordt vaak gebruikt als pigment of als vulstof voor linoleum.

General term for various earthy materials containing silica, alumina, and iron oxides; often contains compounds of barium or calcium. Occurs in yellowish, brown, or reddish colors.Ochers are also used as pigment, colorants in ceramic slips and glazes, added as a reducing agent in luster glazes, and as a filler in linoleum and other products.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ocher (inorganic material)
oker
oker (anorganisch materiaal)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any greasy substance that is liquid at room temperature and insoluble in water. Fixed (nonvolatile) oils have the same chemical composition as fats: they consist chiefly of glycerides, resulting from a reaction between glycerol and fatty acids. Oils may be divided by function and type: mineral (e.g., paraffin), vegetable (e.g., linseed), animal (e.g., fish), essential (e.g., turpentine), or edible (e.g., olive).

Een ietwat stroperige, neutrale en brandbare vette substantie, meestal vloeibaar of gemakkelijk smeltbaar bij verwarming. Het is onoplosbaar in water en laat een vettige vlek achter op papier of textiel.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oil (organic material)
olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil obtained from animal substances.
Olie verkregen uit dierlijke stoffen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: animal oil
dierlijke olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless, aliphatic hydrocarbon oil obtained from petroleum distilled at 330-360 degrees C.
Olie verkregen uit aardolie of schalie.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mineral oil
minerale olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil extracted from plant parts, such as seeds, fruits, or nuts. They contain a mixture of glycerides and may be considered drying, sem-drying, or nondrying.
Olie verkregen uit planten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plantaardige olie
vegetable oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aromatic oil found in uncombined form in various parts of plants and employed for flavoring, perfume, disenfectant, and medicine.
Aromatische olie die in ongemengde vorm wordt gevonden in verscheidene plantendelen; wordt gebruikt voor smaakstoffen, parfums, ontsmettingsmiddelen en medicijnen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: essential oil
etherische olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An essential oil obtained from the dried flower buds of clove tree (Eugenia caryophyllata or Syzygium aromaticum), containing eugenol along with carophyllin, tannin, gum, and resin. Used as an additive used to retard the drying of paint.
Toevoeging gebruikt om het drogen van verf te vertragen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: kruidnagelolie
oil of cloves

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless to yellowish aromatic essential oil obtained from the flowers of several species of lavender; used as a retardant in oil paint.
Een kleurloze tot gelige, aromatische etherische olie die wordt verkregen uit de bloemen van verschillende lavendelsoorten; wordt gebruikt als een vertrager in olieverf.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lavendelolie
lavender oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil distilled from an inferior grade of lavender. Oil of spike is used in painting on porcelain, in soap, scent, and food flavorings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: spijkolie
spike oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A pungent essential oil obtained from the flowering tops of rosemary and used chiefly in soap, cologne, hair lotion, pharmaceutical preparations, and as a retardant in oil paint.

Een scherpe etherische olie verkregen uit de bloeiende toppen van rozemarijn. Het wordt voornamelijk gebruikt in zeep, reukwater, haarwater en farmaceutische preparaten, en als een vertrager in olieverf.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rosemary oil
rozemarijnolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oily fat-based lubricant often derived from rendered animal parts, or a synthetic petroleum-derived product resembling this. Oily fat-based lubricant often derived from rendered animal parts, or a synthetic petroleum-derived product resembling this.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: grease
smeer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An oil or oily preparation used on cutting tools or on work being machined to aid in the cutting action.
Een olie of olieachtig preparaat dat wordt gebruikt op snijgereedschap of op materiaal dat wordt bewerkt om te helpen bij het snijden.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cutting oil
snijolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Petroleum products, usually heavy distillates after kerosene, that are classified based on their viscosity for various purposes, ranging from very thin oils for high speed textile machinery, to heavier, tackier, or stickier oils for bearings or open gears. Automobile oil is the most common in the United States.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lubricating oil
smeerolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A thickened oil obtained by blowing a fatty acid, such as linseed oil or fish oil; used in paint and varnish as a drying oil and in lubricant.
Een geconcentreerde olie die wordt verkregen door een vetzuur te blazen, zoals lijnzaadolie of visolie; wordt in verf en vernis gebruikt als een drogende olie en in smeermiddelen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: blown oil
geblazen olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any vegetable oil that has been extracted from seeds or nuts by pressing them without the aid of heat.
Elke plantaardige olie die uit zaden of noten is verkregen door ze te persen zonder warmte toe te voegen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cold-pressed oil
koud-geperste olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A commercial grade of linseed oil that is the slowest-drying.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: raw oil
ruwe olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil converted into a soap or crystalline form through combination with an alkali.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: saponified oil
verzeepte olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Heavy viscous material resulting from the polymerization of an oil, such as linseed oil; used chiefly in painting and glazing mediums; unlike raw oil, tends not to yellow with age.

Zwaar, stroperig materiaal dat ontstaat door de polymerisatie van een olie, bijvoorbeeld lijnzaadolie; wordt voornamelijk gebruikt in bindmiddelen voor verf en vernis. In tegenstelling tot ruwe olie vergeelt deze olie niet met ouderdom.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: stand oil
standolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Polymerized stand oil of increased viscosity, created by heat in the absence of oxygen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: middelolie
middle oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oils prepared by natural thickening in sunlight. This is most often a linseed oil. Sun-thickened oil is similar to stand oil, but is prized for is fast-drying properties as a painting medium.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: door zon ingedikte olie
sun-thickened oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any oil that will solidify to a tough, leathery film when spread out in thin layers, either alone or with the assistance of a drier.
Elke olie die verhardt tot een taai, leerachtig vlies wanneer het in dunne lagen wordt aangebracht, ofwel op zichzelf of met behulp van een droogmiddel.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: drogende olie
drying oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A drying oil whose drying properties have been increased.
Een drogende olie waarvan de drogende eigenschappen zijn verhoogd.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bodied oil
gekookte lijnolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil used as a substitute for linseed oil.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bankoelnootolie
candlenut oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil obtained from fish and marine animals.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fish oil
traan
traan (dierlijke olie)
visolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil obtained from the seeds of the hemp plant. Used as a substitute for linseed oil.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hempseed oil
hennepzaadolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een veelgebruikte, drogende olie die als oplosmiddel in verf wordt gebruikt; verhardt in de loop van enkele weken wanneer delen van de olie polymeriseren en een onoplosbaar bindmiddel vormen.
Popular drying oil used as a paint medium; hardens over several weeks as components of the oil polymerize to form an insoluble matrix.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lijnzaadolie
linseed oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Linseed oil prepared by heating to less than 600 F in a closed container to eliminate oxygenation. It dries quickly and creates a hard film.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: boiled oil
gekookte olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Lijnzaadolie die bij hoge temperatuur verhit wordt met zoveel wit lood of loodglit als er mee verbonden kan worden.
Linseed oil cooked at a high temperature with as much white lead or litharge as will combine with it.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: black oil
zwarte olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A drying oil obtained from the kernel of the fruit of the oiticica tree that is similar to tung oil; used chiefly in varnish, paint, and printing ink.
Een drogende olie verkregen uit de pit van de vruchten van de oiticica-boom. De olie lijkt op tungolie en wordt hoofdzakelijk gebruikt in vernis, verf en drukinkt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oiticica oil
oiticica olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Drying oil used in house and industrial paint, linoleum, and printing ink.
Een drogende olie die voor huis- en industriële verf wordt gebruikt, in linoleum en in drukinkt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: perilla oil
perilla olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil obtained from the seeds of the opium poppy, Papaver somniferum. When cold pressed, it is a naturally, colorless, transparent oil used as a drying oil, sometimes used as an additive to linseed-oil colors. Hot pressed oil is reddish. It produces a soft, rubbery paint film with a long wet-in-wet work time that was popular with Impressionist painters. Thick layers of poppy oil paint films tend to wrinkle and crack on aging.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: papaverolie
poppy-seed oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A pale, non-yellowing drying oil of good film-forming properties and excellent color retention.
Een bleke, niet vergelende, drogende olie met goede laagvormende eigenschappen en een uitstekend kleurbehoud.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: saffloerolie
safflower oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A pale yellow drying oil obtained from soya beans. It is frequently used in paint and varnish, and sometimes mixed with linseed oil.
Een lichtgele, drogende olie afkomstig uit sojabonen; wordt gebruikt in verf en lak en soms vermengd met lijnzaadolie.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sojaolie
soybean oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A pale yellow drying oil with a pleasant odor and taste obtained from the large seeds of the common sunflower plant.
Een bleekgele, drogende olie met een aangename geur en smaak, afkomstig uit de grote zaden van de gewone zonnebloem.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sunflower oil
zonnebloemolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil made from tobacco seeds and used as a drying oil. It has an iodine value of 140 to 146.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tabakszaadolie
tobacco seed oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A semidrying oil used in hardwearing varnish and enamel.
Een halfdrogende olie die wordt gebruikt in duurzame vernis en email.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tung oil
tungolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil derived from the nuts of the tree Aleurites cordata. It does not gelatinize when heated and is used for varnishes, waterproofing, paper and soaps.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Japanese tung oil
Japanse tungolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A yellowish drying oil used especially for artist's paint.
Een gelige, drogende olie die voornamelijk wordt gebruikt voor het maken van verf voor kunstschilders.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: walnootolie
walnut oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A vegetable oil such as corn or soybean oil, that can be made to dry or form a solid film by chemical treatment, but does not do so on simple exposure to air, as does a drying oil; not used in artists' oil paint.

Een plantaardige olie zoals maïs- of sojaolie, die men door een chemische behandeling kan laten drogen of een vast laagje kan laten vormen; dit gebeurt echter niet gewoon bij blootstelling aan lucht zoals bij een drogende olie. Wordt niet gebruikt in olieverf voor kunstschilders.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: half-drogende olie
semidrying oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil made from the cotton plant, and popular as a food oil, such as in salad oils and margarine. Cottonseed oil also has a wide range of industrial uses, such as an ingredient in soaps and paint oils.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cottonseed oil
katoenzaadolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Yellow-brown poisonous oil derived from the seeds of the tree Croton tiglium native to India and Sri Lanka. Originally used as a purgative and as a substitute for castor oil, it is now thought too dangerous for medicinal purposes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: croton oil
crotonolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Yellow oil derived from the kernels of seeds of Jatropha curcas, native to Central America. This oil is used in cooking, soap, and as a strong purgative.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: curcas oil
curcas olie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A semidrying oil obtained from the seeds of the kapok tree.
Een halfdrogende olie onttrokken aan de zaden van de kapokboom.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: kapok oil
kapokolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Edible oil obtained from corn kernels, valued for its transparent flavor and light colour. It is used in a variety of edible and inedible products including cosmetics. Edible oil obtained from corn kernels, valued for its transparent flavor and light colour. It is used in a variety of edible and inedible products including cosmetics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: corn oil
maïsolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil characterized by lower iodine values. These oils will remain viscous within a range of moderate temperature indefinitely.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: niet-drogende olie
nondrying oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless or pale yellow bland and nearly odorless nondrying fatty oil used as an emollient.
Een kleurloze of lichtgele, vrijwel geurloze, niet-drogende vette olie zonder veel smaak die wordt gebruikt als zachtmakend middel.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: almond oil
amandelolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Viscous, clear to pale yellow non-volatile fatty oil obtained from the seeds of Ricinus communis or Palma Christi of the spurge family, having a nauseating taste. Used in medicine as a purgative, and also in the production of synthetic resins, plastics, fibres, paints, varnishes, drying oils, and plasticizers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: castor oil
castorolie
purgeerolie
ricinusolie
wonderolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Generally, an oil that is extracted from the kernel or pit of a fruit.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: kernel oil
pitolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil obtained from mustard seeds, characterized as a nondrying oil primarily used in food products, medicines, and a plasticizer with drying oils and with natural and synthetic resins.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mosterdolie
mustard oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil extracted from the ripe fruit of olive trees, and used mainly for food and cooking oil.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: olijfolie
olive oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil extracted from the seed kernel of the peanut. The oil is edible and used for cooking, but is also used in soaps and fuels.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: arachideolie
peanut oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An oil obtained from seeds of the mustard family.
Een olie verkregen uit zaden van de mosterdfamilie.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: koolzaadolie
rape oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil obtained from rice bran and used in cooking.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rice oil
rijstolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A water-dispersible cleansing and emulsifying agent produced by the saponification reaction of long chain fatty acids, such as found in oils and fats, with an alkali, such as sodium hydroxide or lye. Soaps made from animal fat and wood ashes have been used since antiquity. Although soap was made at home for laundry purposes from the European Middle Ages to early modern times, cake soap was a luxury product that came into common use only in the 19th century.
Een reinigend en emulgerend middel dat wordt verkregen door olie, vet, hars of was te koken met een alkali .
owl:Class.rdfs:label: soap (organic material)
zeep
zeep (organisch materiaal)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Ongeconsolideerd materiaal op het aardoppervlak dat ontstaat door de verwering van gesteente en dat deel van het aardoppervlak dat planten in leven kan houden.
Unconsolidated material on the earth's surface formed by the weathering of rock and that portion of the earth's surface that can support plant life.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: grond
grond (materiaal)
soil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Alle grondsoorten, vooral klei, die in Ethiopië met water worden gemengd om mortel te maken.
Any kind of earth, especially clay, that is mixed with water to make mortar in Ethiopia.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: chika
chika

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dark brown or black non-living organic substance derived from microbial decomposition of plant and animal substances on the surface of the earth. Living plants derive nutrients from the forms created by this decomposition.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: humus
humus

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A residual product of rock decay that is red in color and has a high content in the oxides of iron and hydroxide of aluminum and a low proportion of silica. Used in African and Asian building construction.

Een restproduct van de verwering van gesteente, dat rood van kleur is, een hoog gehalte aan ijzeroxiden en aluminiumhydroxide bevat en een klein deel silicaat. Wordt gebruikt in Afrikaanse bouwwerken.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lateriet
laterite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een zachte, gemakkelijke bewerkbare grondsoort die zand, slib en klei bevat.
Soft, easily worked soil containing sand, silt, and clay.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: leem
loam

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Grond die zoveel water bevat dat deze zacht en ten minste half vloeibaar is.
Soil containing so much water that it is soft and at least semi-fluid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: modder
mud

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An unconsolidated deposit of semicarbonized plant remains formed in a water-saturated environment such as a bog.
Een zwakkere afzetting van half inzetgeharde overblijfselen van planten, gevormd in een omgeving die is verzadigd met water zoals een moeras.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: peat
turf
turf (peat)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material consisting of fragmented particles of mostly siliceous rock, specifically as it appears on the surface of a beach or a desert. Individual particles may range in diameter from approximately 0.0008-0.08 inch. Most rock-forming minerals at the Earth's surface may be constituents of sand, but a limited number are common. Quartz is most common.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sand
zand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Bestaat grotendeels uit glauconiet, een groenachtig, korrelig mineraal dat tot 25% ijzer kan bevatten, met een hoog percentage aan silica en wat kaliumcarbonaat en aluminium; wordt vooral gebruikt als waterverzachter en als bron voor kaliumcarbonaat.

Consists largely of glauconite, a greenish granular mineral containing up to 25% iron, with a large percentage of silica and some potash and aluminum, used especially as a water softener and as a source of potash.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: greensand (soil)
groenzand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Geselecteerd zand dat wordt gebruikt in beton, mortel, pleisterwerk en voor het leggen van stenen.
Selected sand used for concrete, for mortar, for laying bricks, and for plastering.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: building sand
metselzand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Floor covering comprising loose sand.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: flooring sand
vloerzand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A building sand graded for three separate purposes: concrete pavement, asphalt pavement, and grouting.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: paving sand
straatzand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A fine white silica sand.
Een fijn, wit silicazand.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: roofing sand
roofing sand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any sand employed for making molds for casting metal, but especially refers to refractory sand that has binding qualities.
Elk zand dat wordt gebruikt voor het maken van vormen voor het gieten van metaal, maar vooral betrekking hebbend op hittebestendig zand dat zich laat binden.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: foundry sand
gietzand
vormzand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sand employed in glassmaking.
Zand gebruikt voor het maken van glas.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: glass sand
glaszand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sand comprised of silica, which is 98% pure, and used in glassmaking.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: kiezelzuurzand
silica sand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sand employed in a blast of air for cleaning castings, removal of paint, cleaning of metal articles, and for giving a dull, rough finish to glass or metal goods.

Zand dat wordt gebruikt in een luchtstraal voor het schoonmaken van gegoten voorwerpen en metalen artikelen, de verwijdering van verf en voor het geven van een doffe, ruwe afwerking aan glazen of metalen goederen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sandblast sand
schuurzand

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Fijne, witte klei gemengd met kalk; wordt voornamelijk als bouw- en pleistermateriaal gebruikt en voor sculpturen.
Fine white clay mixed with lime; used chiefly as building and plastering material, and for sculpture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: zaccab
zaccab

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Coarse, granular, sandlike substance that consists chiefly of clay, made into a mortar used in African building construction.
Een grove, korrelige, zandachtige substantie die hoofdzakelijk uit klei bestaat; wordt in Afrika tot een mortel gemaakt die wordt gebruikt in de bouw.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: daga
daga (soil)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Construction material consisting of daga, which is a coarse, granular, sandlike substance, that has been burnt to increase its durability and impermeability.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: burnt daga
burnt daga

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sections of earth together with the grass growing on them, held together with matted roots, usually square or oblong in shape and of moderate thickness, cut out or pared off from the surface of grass land.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: graszoden
plaggen
sod (soil)
zoden

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Grond die van een andere locatie is ontleend om in de bouw te worden gebruikt.
Soil borrowed from another location to be used in construction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aangevoerde grond
borrow soil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A building material consisting of stiff earth or clay forced in between forms.
Een bouwmateriaal dat bestaat uit stevige aarde of klei die tussen vormen in is gedrukt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pisé
pisé

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A material usually consisting of clay, sand, or other aggregate, such as sea shell, and water, which has been compressed and dried; used in building construction.
Een materiaal dat meestal bestaat uit klei, zand of een andere samenstelling zoals zeeschelpen en water, en is samengeperst en gedroogd; wordt gebruikt voor bouwwerken.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rammed earth
stampaarde

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Clay with a component of fine gravel used to make bricks or otherwise puddled, rammed, and dried. Primarily used for wall construction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tapia
tapia

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Portland cement mixed with the existing soil to serve as a paving or surfacing material.
Portlandcement gemengd met de aanwezige aarde om als bestrating of wegdekmateriaal te dienen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gestabiliseerd zand
soil cement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A synthetic polymer with elastic properties similar to natural rubber that can recover its original size after repeated extensions to more than twice its initial length. Examples of elastomers are polybutadiene, styrene-butadiene rubber, nitrile rubber, and butyl rubber.
Polymeermateriaal dat na het rekken terugkeert tot ongeveer de oorspronkelijke lengte.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: elastomeer
elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An ethylene-propylene elastomer noted for resistance to oils, ozone, weathering and heat.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: epichlorohydrin elastomer
epichlorohydrin elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A commercially produced rubber with high chemical resistance and tear strength.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ethyleen-propyleen elastomeer
ethylene-propylene elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Elastomeer dat het meest bestand is tegen oxidatie, chemische producten, olie, oplosmiddelen en hitte; veelvoorkomende toepassingen zijn remvoeringen, O-ringen, pessariums en brandslangen.
Elastomer which is highest in resistance to oxidation, chemicals, oil, solvent, and heat; typical applications are brake seals, O rings, diaphragms, and hose.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fluorcarbon elastomeer
fluorocarbon elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A synthetic rubber which is a copolymer of isobyutylene, and 1 to 3% isoprene.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: butyl rubber
butyl rubber

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Synthetic rubber made by polymerization of chloroprene and characterized by superior resistance to oil, gasoline, sunlight, ozone, and heat, and by lower permeability to gas than rubber.

Synthetisch rubber gemaakt door polymerisatie van chloropreen en gekenmerkt door de uitstekende bestendigheid tegen olie, benzine, zonlicht, ozon en warmte, en doordat de doorlaatbaarheid voor gas minder is dan van rubber.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: neopreen
neoprene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An oil-resistant synthetic rubber or copolymer of acrylonitrile and butadiene used in such applications as oil well parts, gaskets, rollers, or fuel hoses.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nitril elastomeer
nitrile elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A class of elastomers that is notable for performance at low temperatures, resilience, and abrasion resistance. Used for shoe heels and soles, gaskets, and belting. Combined with other rubbers to improve their resilience and flexibility at low temperatures.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polybutadien elastomeer
polybutadiene elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Polymeric substance prepared from derivatives of ethylene that are capable of recovering their original shape after being stretched to great extents.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyethyleen elastomeer
polyethylene elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Isoprene polymer which includes the main constituent in natural rubber.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyisoprene
polysupreen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Synthetic rubber formed from a salt or other compound which contains two or more sulfur atoms bonded together as an anion or group that are capable of recovering their original shape after being stretched to great extents.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polysulfide elastomeer
polysulfide elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Semi-inorganic polymers based on siloxanes that will return to approximate original length after stretching, and that demonstrate heat, chemical, and water resistance.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silicone elastomeer
silicone elastomer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Elastomer with a high degree of solvent resistance and excellent low-temperature capabilities created by the addition of fluorine into a polyalkylsilsiloxane system.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fluorosilicone elastomer
fluorsilicone elastomeer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Synthetic rubber made by the copolymerization of two compounds (one being butadiene) and a catalyst (sodium).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: styreenbutatieenrubber
styrene-butadiene rubber

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Copolymers of diisocyanate with polyester or polyether. Urethane is the strongest available elastomer, and has good abrasion resistance. Applications include parts requiring high wear resistance, such as wheels, heels, and bumpers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: urethaan elastomeer
urethane elastomer (organic material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plastic dat zacht wordt bij verhitting en hard bij afkoeling ongeacht het aantal keren dat deze processen worden herhaald, als gevolg van weinig of geen onderlinge bindingen tussen de moleculen.
Plastic that becomes soft when heated and hard when cooled, no matter how often these processes are repeated, because of little or no cross-bonding between molecules.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: thermoplast
thermoplastic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic with applications in appliance, automotive, and business machine manufacture, among others. Available in varied grades, ABS consists of discrete , crosslinked rubber particles that are grafted with polystyrene-co-acrylonitrile and embedded in a SAN matrix.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: acrylonitril-butadieen-styreen copolymeer
acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene copolymer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een zeer kristallijne hars die tot de sterkste en stugste soorten thermoplastic behoort.
Highly crystalline resin that is among the strongest and stiffest types of thermoplastic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: acetaal
acetal (thermoplastic)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless, transparent, thermoplastic synthetic resin made by the polymerization of acrylic acid derivatives; used for adhesives, fibers, consolidants, protective coatings, finishes, and as a paint medium.

Een kleurloze, transparante, thermoplastische, synthetische hars gemaakt door de polymerisatie van acrylzuur derivaten; wordt gebruikt voor hechtmiddelen, verharders, beschermlagen, vernis en als een bindmiddel in verven.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: acryl
acryl (thermoplast)
acrylic (resin)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A polymer of acrylic acid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyacrylaat
polyacrylate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic made from cellulose or a cellulose compound.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cellulose
cellulose (thermoplast)
cellulosic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A tough, flammable, easily fabricated thermoplastic polymer composed of acetic acid ester of cellulose. Forms include white flakes or powder; it is used in a variety of products such as acetate fiber, lacquers, photographic film, magnetic tapes, lacquers, and transparent sheeting. The substance was first developed in 1865; in 1908 it was introduced as safety film by Eastman Kodak, replacing flammable cellulose nitrate film. As the cellulose acetate ages, the added plasticizers can migrate to the surface producing an oily film.

Een sterk, brandbaar en eenvoudig te fabriceren hars van thermoplast, die voorkomt als witte schilfers of poeder. Wordt gebruikt voor verschillende producten, zoals acetaatvezel, lakken, fotografische film en magnetische banden.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cellulose acetaat
cellulose acetate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A class of water-soluble polymers with a cellulose backbone and ether-containing substituents. Cellulose ethers are white bulky solids that form clear, hygroscopic films. They are made by treating cellulose with concentrated sodium hydroxide followed by etherification with one or more reagents such as methyl chloride, ethyl chloride, ethylene oxide or propylene oxide. They are used as adhesives, poultices, consolidants, and coatings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cellulose ether
cellulose ether

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless, odorless ester of cellulose resulting from the reaction of ethyl chloride and cellulose; forms a durable alkali-resistant coating.
Een kleurloze, reukloze ester van cellulose, die het gevolg is van de reactie van ethylchloride met cellulose; het vormt een duurzame alkali-bestendige deklaag.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ethyl cellulose
ethyl cellulose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Substance comprising a mixture of nitric esters of cellulose and a highly flammable compound containing more than approximately 12.5 percent nitrogen. Nitrocellulose is a fluffy white substance that retains some of the fibrous structure of untreated cellulose. It is not stable to heat and will ignite easily. It was first introduced in the 19th century as an explosive. It was used to produce animation cels for 80 years until acetate was introduced as a safer medium in the 1950s. Cellulose nitrate was often used for clear lacquers, fabric dopes, adhesives, high-gloss paints, and mixed with natural resins (dammar, shellac, copal, etc) to create a waterproof varnish. Cellulose nitrate is inherently unstable and slowly decomposes at room temperature.

Verwijst naar een mengsel van genitreerde cellulose, een uiterst brandbare verbinding die het hoofdbestanddeel vormt van modern buskruit. Het is gedurende 80 jaar gebruikt om celanimaties te vervaardigen tot de introductie van acetaat als medium in de jaren 50 van de 20ste eeuw. Nitrocellulose is een luchtige witte substantie waarin de vezelachtige structuur van onbehandelde cellulose enigszins behouden is gebleven. Het blijft niet stabiel bij hitte en vat gemakkelijk vlam.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nitrocellulose
nitrocellulose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A tough, highly flammable but not usually explosive, synthetic thermoplastic composed essentially of cellulose nitrate and camphor or another plasticizer. It was originally a trademark of Hoechst Celanese. It was marketed as a substitute for ivory, horn, amber, tortoiseshell for use in piano keys, dolls, buttons, combs, brushes, mirrors, collars, dental plates, and other small items. Tough, transparent sheets and strips of celluloid were also used for photographic and motion picture films as well as animation cels. Celluloid film was cast from a solution of cellulose nitrate with wood alcohol (methanol), amyl nitrate, camphor and fusel oil (amyl alcohol).
Een taai, synthetisch thermoplastic dat zeer brandbaar is maar meestal niet explosief; hoofdzakelijk samengesteld uit cellulose-nitraat met kamfer of een andere weekmaker.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: celluloid
celluloid (cellulosic)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A flammable mixture of cellulose nitrates usually with less than 12.5% nitrogen.
Een brandbaar mengsel van cellulose-nitraten, dat meestal minder dan 12,5% stikstof bevat.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pyroxylin
pyroxyline

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een bepaalde plasticsoort die wordt gekenmerkt door bestendigheid tegen agressieve omgevingen, waaronder extreme weersomstandigheden en temperaturen van bijna 0 tot 260 graden Celsius.
Type of plastic characterized by resistance to aggressive environments, including extremes of weather, and temperatures ranging from near 0 to 260 degrees Celsius.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fluoroplastic
fluorplastic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic or resin used for bonding brick and tile.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: furan
furan

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Polymer composed of macromolecules in which a small but significant proportion of the constitutional units has ionic or inonizable groups, or both.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ionomeer polymeer
ionomer polymer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of a variety of thermoplastic polymers originally developed as textile fibers and used in fabrics. They have a straight-chain polyamide structure and are largely heat-resistant.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nylon
nylon

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Handelsmerk voor een commercieel gefabriceerde aramidesoort, een synthetisch textielmateriaal dat licht is, niet brandbaar en zeer schokbestendig.
Trademark for a type of commercially produced aramid, a synthetic textile material which is lightweight, nonflammable, and has a high impact resistance.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Kevlar
Kevlar (TM)
Kevlar (TM)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic polymer group which includes nylon and other synthetic resins.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyamide
polyamide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic polymer of butylene, formerly used for water pipes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polybutyleen
polybutylene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic polyester used in glazing, including bullet- and explosion-resistant laminates.
Thermoplastisch polyester dat wordt gebruikt voor beglazing, met inbegrip van kogel- en explosiebestendige laminaten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polycarbonaat
polycarbonate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Amorphous, high-temperature, yellowish or transparent thermoplastic developed in 1982 with a molecular weight of Tg = 215C. Characteristics include resistance to ultraviolet and gamma radiation. May be used as reinforcing fiber or as fire-resistant material in electrical components, jets, and automobiles. Resistant to aliphatic hydrocarbons, alcohols, and dilute bases.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyetherimide
polytherimide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A group of polyolefin polymers derived from ethylene by polymerization by heat and pressure.
Een groep polyolefin polymeren afgeleid van ethyleen door middel van polymerisatie onder verhitting en druk.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyethyleen
polyethylene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een taaie, lichte, stijve kunststof die wordt vervaardigd door de polymerisering van zeer zuiver propyleengas met een metaalorganische katalysator bij een relatief lage druk en temperatuur.
Tough, lightweight, rigid plastic made by the polymerization of high-purity propylene gas in the presence of an organometallic catalyst at relatively low pressure and temperature.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polypropyleen
polypropylene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A clear plastic or stiff foam, a polymer of styrene, used chiefly as an insulator in refrigerators, air conditioners, and for packaging.
Een helder plastic of stug schuim, een polymeer van styreen, die hoofdzakelijk wordt gebruikt als isolatiemateriaal in koelkasten en airconditioningsapparaten, en als verpakkingsmateriaal.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: piepschuim
polystyreen
polystyrene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plastic based on polyether or polyester resin.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyurethaan
polyurethane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Copolymer plastic composed of styrene and acrylonitrile that has high thermal resistance.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: styrene-acrylonitrile
styrene-acrylonitrile

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Amorphous high-performance thermoplastic characterized by aryl groups linked by sulfo and ether groups.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sulfone polymer
sulfone polymer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Generic term for materials derived from vinyl chloride, vinyl acetate, or vinylidene chloride. Commonly used with reference to all polymers and copolymers of which vinyl chloride is a constituent. Use more precise terminology for known materials such as "polyvinyl chloride" or "polyvinyl acetate."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vinyl
vinyl

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of a group of thermoplastic resins made by condensing polyvinyl alcohol with an aldehyde and used chiefly in the form of sheets and films, molded products, coatings, adhesives; especially, the resin made from acetaldehyde.

Groep van thermoplastische harsen die worden vervaardigd door polyvinylalcohol te condenseren met een aldehyde; wordt voornamelijk gebruikt in de vorm van platen en vliezen, gegoten producten, deklagen en hechtmiddelen. Het gaat hierbij speciaal om hars gemaakt van acetaldehyde.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinyl acetal
polyvinylacetaal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Synthetic resin derived from the polymerization of vinyl acetate. Used primarily as the filming agent in water-based paints, and also as an ingredient in adhesives.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinyl acetate
polyvinylacetaat

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A thermoplastic resin that is soluble or swells in water and can become insoluble in time through crosslinking; used chiefly for emulsifier, adhesive, and film resistant to solvent and abrasion, and in making molded and extruded products, and polyvinyl acetal.

Een thermoplastische hars die in water oplost of uitzet en na een verloop van tijd onoplosbaar kan worden als gevolg van het ontstaan van onderlinge bindingen; het wordt hoofdzakelijk gebruikt als emulgator, hechtmiddel en laagjes die bestendig zijn tegen oplossing en slijtage. Het wordt ook gebruikt voor het maken van gegoten en geëxtrudeerde producten en polyvinylacetaal.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinyl alcohol
polyvinylalcohol

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A tough, flexible, transparent, moistureproof polyvinyl acetal resin made from polyvinyl alcohol and butyraldehyde; used, among other things, as the interlayer in safety glass and other laminated products.

Een taaie, soepele, transparante en vochtbestendige polyvinylacetaalhars gemaakt van polyvinylalcohol en butyraldehyde; wordt onder andere gebruikt als tussenlaag in veiligheidsglas en andere gelamineerde producten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinyl butyral
polyvinylbutyraat

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A thermoplastic resin derived by the polymerization of vinyl chloride, used for thin coatings, insulation, and pipes.
Een thermoplastische hars verkregen door de polymerisatie van vinylchloride; wordt onder andere gebruikt voor dunne deklagen, isolatie en buizen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinyl chloride
polyvinylchloride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A polymer with strong intermolecular bonding that becomes rigid by chemical reaction and that is not remeltable. Thermoset polymers are usually insoluble in most solvents. Examples of thermoset polymers are epoxies, silicones, and phenolics along with some polyesters and polyurethanes.
Plastic met sterke intermoleculaire binding, dat onbuigzaam wordt door chemische reacties en niet meer kan worden gesmolten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: thermoharder
thermoset

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of a variety of synthetic resins, produced by the esterification of a polybasic acid with a polyhydric alcohol. Often used for coatings, finishes, adhesives, and molding compounds.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: alkyd resin
alkydhars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Resin made by polymerization of chemical compunds containg the allyl group.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: allyl resin
allylhars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any thermosetting plastic made by polycondensation of a compound containing amino groups such as urea or melamine, with an aldehyde, such as formaldehyde or another aldehyde-yeilding substance. Amino resins were first made in 1929. Examples of amino resins are melamine formaldehyde and urea formaldehyde. Amino resins are used for molded plastics, coatings, adhesives, laminating, textile finishes, and paper manufacture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: amino resin
aminohars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white, crystalline, slightly water-soluble solid used chiefly in organic synthesis and in the manufacture of resin, especially melamine resin.
Een witte, kristallijne vaste stof die enigszins oplosbaar is in water en voornamelijk wordt gebruikt bij organische synthese en de productie van hars, met name melaminehars.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: melamine
melamine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Resin made by condensing urea or thiourea with formaldehyde.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: urea-formaldehyde resin
ureumformaldehydehars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Resin made by the interaction of an amine and an aldehyde.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: amino-aldehyde hars
aminoaldehyde resin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic molding materials prepared from casein, a natural phosphorous-containing protein found in milk. While trying to make a waterproof coating in 1897, Adolph Spitteler and associate W. Krische of Germany discovered that casein becomes hard and insoluble when treated with formaldehyde. Casein plastics were used for small items such as buttons, beads, buckles, combs, fountain pens, umbrella handles, cutlery handles, and knitting needles; they are often pigmented to simulate ivory, horn, or tortoise shell.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: casein plastic
caseïneplastic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een synthetische harssoort die wordt gebruikt voor de productie van hechtmiddelen die verharden na een chemische reactie, in plaats van door verlies van oplosmiddel en samensmelting.
Type of synthetic resin used to produce adhesive that sets by chemical reaction, rather than through loss of solvent and coalescence.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: epoxy resin
epoxyhars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A commercially important liquid epoxy resin, diglycidyl ether of bisphenol-A, prepared by reaction of epichlorohydrin with bisphenol-A.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: basic liquid epoxy
basische vloeibare epoxyhars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Epoxy resins that exhibit a degree of crosslinking higher than that of standard difunctional resins and that possess adhesive characteristics. Multifunctionality arises as a result of N-glycidyl, O-glycidyl and N- and O-glycidyl groups in the resin structure.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: multifunctional epoxy
multifunctionele epoxyhars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A hybrid binder resin used in various applications such as protective coating or primer on corrosion-prone surfaces of metals and concrete, and in other applications including high-brightness LED packaging.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silicone epoxy
silicone epoxyhars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to any of a large class of synthetic resins made by reacting phenol with formaldehyde. Phenolic resins were the first totally synthetic polymers to be commercialized. Bakelite is a phenolic plastic. Current industrial applications include adhesives in plywood.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fenolhars
phenolic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: De oorspronkelijke benaming voor fenolplastic, die tegenwoordig wordt gebruikt voor een aantal verschillende soorten plastic.

The original trademarked name for phenol-formaldehyde resin, but now used to refer to a range of different types of plastic. The method for manufacturing the original resin was devised in 1909 by L. H. Baekeland in the United States, and the name Bakelite is a registered trademark of the Union Carbide Corporation. It is a hard, infusible, and chemically resistant plastic, nonconductor of electricity, and used in electrical appliances, industrial applications, in molding and casting operations, as an adhesive, in paints, and in baked-enamel coatings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Bakelite (TM)
bakeliet

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Molding powder first introduced by Bakelite Ltd. in the early 1960s. Characteristics of this material include a range of intense bright colors. They have a good molding latitude and dry heat dimensional stability. Applications include handles for appliances where heat-resistant colored material is called for.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: melamine fenol
melamine phenolic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Resin formed by the reaction between dibasic acid and dihydroxy alcohol.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyester
polyester (resin)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Synthetic resin that is produced by the polymerization of vinylidene chloride. Discovered in 1933, and developed as a flexible film primarily used as a food wrap, initially marketed as "Saran Wrap." It is used as a barrier against water, oxygen and vapor. Chemically resistant to alkalies and acids, it is insoluble in oil and organic solvents, and is impervious to mold, bacteria, and insects.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinylideenchloride
polyvinylidene chloride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A superpolymer that maintains mechanical and chemical integrity above 400 degrees Fahrenheit for extended periods and has high strength and modulus of elasticity and excellent resistance to solvent, oil, and corrosive environment.

Een superpolymeer die bij temperaturen boven de 200 graden Celsius voor lange tijd de oorspronkelijke mechanische en chemische toestand aanhoudt; het is zeer sterk en elastisch en is uitstekende bestand tegen oplosmiddelen, olie en corrosieve omstandigheden.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyimide
polyimide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any solid semi-inorganic polymers based on siloxanes, obtained by the action of concentrated hydrochloric acid on calcium silicide. Silicones were first discovered by F.S. Kipping in England in 1904, but were not commercially produced as polymers until 1943 by Dow Corning and 1946 by General Electric. They were called silicones because their empirical formula (R2SiO) is similar to that for ketones (R2CO). Silicones can be liquids, gels, and elastomers as well as solid thermoplastic or thermosetting resins. In general, they have excellent heat and chemical resistance and are water repellent. Silicones are used as adhesives, lubricants, protective coatings, release agents, paints, rubbers, coolants, implants, and insulation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silicone
siliconen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Light spongy rubber made by mechanically whipping air into the rubber latex prior to curing. It is used for mattresses, cushions, and insulation. Foam rubber turns yellow and becomes powdery when exposed to sunlight.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: foam rubber
polyether
schuimrubber

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Lightweight and buoyant polymers containing uniformly dispersed air pockets, like a sponge. They are made from most types of polymers (rubber, polyethylene, polystyrene, epoxy, polyurethane, vinyl resins, silicone resins, and others). Steam, air or an inert gas is mechanically added or chemically produced in the plastic resins during manufacture to form a cured open cellular structure. They may be soft and spongy (foam rubber, polyethylene, etc.) or rigid and strong (polystyrene, epoxy). Closed-cell foams have individual non-connected bubbles while open-cell foams have an interconnected tunnels formed when the incorporated gas or steam escapes during cure.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plastic foam
schuimplastic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A general term for any of a large and varied class of natural or synthetic organic materials that can be molded, extruded, or cast when soft or liquid, and then set into a rigid or slightly elastic form. Natural plastics include tree resins, beeswax, gutta-percha, horn, and clay. Synthetic plastics were first made in the 19th century. Plastics are used widely in manufacturing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plastic
plastic (material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Alloys created between two or more thermoplastic resins to allow resin polymers to be blended that cannot be polymerized.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plastic alloy
plastic legering

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plastics with additives applied to their formulation, usually adhesion promoters combined with particulate filler for reinforcing molding compounds, or fibers for reinforcing composite materials.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: filled plastic
gevuld plastic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plastic formulations that are not adulterated with fillers such as particles or fibers to increase stiffness or strength.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: onopgevuld plastic
unfilled plastic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plastics formed in an extrusion process, in which a molten polymer is passed from an extruder head and blown into a bubble of uniform film that is then molded, often into food packaging such as bottles for liquid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: extrusieblazen
extrusion blown plastic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Resin-impregnated materials, such as paper or fabric, produced under heat and high pressure to form an insoluble homogeneous piece. Laminates were first made in 1907 by Leo Baekeland when he coated canvas with phenol formaldehyde. Distinguished from "laminated plastic" which is a thin sheet of superimposed layers of plastic bonded or impregnated with resin and compressed under heat.

Te gebruiken voor met hars geïmpregneerde materialen zoals papier of stof, die zijn vervaardigd onder hoge temperaturen en druk. Te onderscheiden van 'gelamineerde kunststof' die bestaat uit een dun vel van op elkaar gelegde lagen plastic, gehecht of geïmpregneerd met hars en onder verhitting samengeperst.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gelaagd plastic
plastic laminate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Handelsmerk voor een bepaald soort commercieel geproduceerd plasticlaminaat dat wordt gemaakt door lagen materialen zoals canvas, glas, papier of linnen aan elkaar te hechten met thermohardende harsen.
Plastic laminate made by bonding layers of materials such as canvas, glass, paper, or linen with thermosetting resins. May be used to refer to the trademarked product and to similar materials.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Formica (TM)
formica

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Handelsmerk voor een soort commercieel geproduceerd plastic laminaat dat wordt gemaakt door lagen stof of papier bij hoge temperaturen en onder druk te hechten met hars; wordt vervaardigd in de vorm van platen, staven en buizen of andere vormen.

Plastic laminate made by bonding layers of cloth or paper with a resin under heat and pressure; made in sheet, rod, and tube form, and in other molded shapes. May be used to refer to the trademarked product and to similar materials.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Micarta
Micarta (TM)
Micarta (TM)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any composite plastic imbedded with high-strength fillers, resulting in mechanical properties superior to base resins. Reinforcement may be derived from fibers, filaments, mats, fabrics made of glass, metal, carbon, boron, or aluminum silicate. The types of plastics used for base resins include polyester, epoxy, phenolic, polypropylene, polystyrene, nylon, polycarbonate, and polyphenylene oxide.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: reinforced plastic
versterkt kunststof

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aanduiding voor diverse materialen die, hoewel ze geen chemisch homogene groep vormen, bepaalde fysieke kenmerken gemeen hebben, en meestal vast en doorschijnend zijn en een laag smeltpunt hebben.

Any solid or semi-solid substance that is slightly greasy to touch, usually solid, translucent, and has a low melting point; waxes are not a chemically homogeneous group. Waxes are composed of long chain hydrocarbon compounds, and may contain esters of fatty acids and alcohols, are thermoplastic and melt at low temperatures of between 40 and 100 C. In general, waxes are water-repellent, smooth, soluble in organic solvents, and classified as animal (e.g., beeswax), vegetable (e.g., bayberry), mineral (e.g., paraffin), or synthetic (e.g., polyethylene). Waxes are used for polishes, candles, crayons, sealants, coatings, adhesives, waterproofing, carbon paper, media in encaustic and wax emulsion paintings, and as repellents in wax-resist watercolor paintings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: was
wax
wax

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of several waxes obtained from animal sources, found in small deposits in many parts of the animal. Animal waxes, such as from a mammal, typically contain no glycerides; they contain sterols (cholesterol) and other long-chain alcohols. Also included are the waxes from insects such as the lac insect which produces shellac. Any of several waxes obtained from animal sources, found in small deposits in many parts of the animal. Animal waxes, such as from a mammal, typically contain no glycerides; they contain sterols (cholesterol) and other long-chain alcohols. Also included are the waxes from insects such as the lac insect which produces shellac.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: animal wax
dierlijke was

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of various waxes that are produced by insects, such as beeswax, lac wax, creosote lac wax, and Chinese insect wax.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: insect wax
insectenwas

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een natuurlijke was die als nevenproduct wordt gemaakt door bijen bij de productie van honing; wordt voornamelijk gebruikt in poetsmiddelen, kaarsen, wasschilderingen, leerbereiding, hechtmiddelen en cosmetica, als een beschermingslaag bij het etsen en om verf te verzachten.

Wax produced by many species of bees, containing around 10% hydrocarbons in addition to alcohols, fatty acids, and esters, with the primary component myricyl palmitate. The wax most commonly used by humans is from Apis mellifera. Beeswax is secreted by the worker bees to form honeycomb cells. The wax is prepared by melting the combs in hot water, then filtering out the resins, sugars, plant materials, and other impurities. The age, diet, location, and species of bee affects the color and texture of the wax. Beeswaxes can be soft or brittle with colors ranging from light yellow to dark brown. The darker varieties are often bleached by exposure to light and air or with chemicals. Beeswax has been used as a protective coating, in etching, for candles, adhesives, paint binder, polish, in encaustic, leather dressing, cosmetics, and to modify paint.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: beeswax
bijenwas

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Beeswax, usually dark in color, that is treated by exposure to light and air or with chemicals to remove the color. For beeswax not treated for color uniformity, use "unbleached beeswax."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bleached beeswax
gebleekte bijenwas

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A particular type of processed beeswax that was used in encaustic paintings. Punic wax was probably made by combining beeswax with soda lime to produce a waxy soap. Repeated washings in hot water removed any excess caustic. Experiments conducted in Berlin to recreate an ancient recipe yielded flakes of a hard brittle wax that melted between 73-75C (163-167 F).
Bewerkte of verwerkte bijenwas die werd gebruikt bij oude encaustische schilderijen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: punic wax
punische was

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Untreated natural beeswax, which is made by bees as a by-product of honey production. For beeswax treated to remove color, use "bleached beeswax."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ongebleekte bijenwas
unbleached beeswax

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een vrij harde, gelig-witte was gemaakt door insecten die door mensen worden gekweekt; wordt gebruikt voor algemene doeleinden en als een vervanger voor bijenwas.

Fairly hard, yellowish-white wax composed primarily of ceryl cerotate and other esters, excreted by the louse-like scale insects of the genus Ceroplastes found in China, Japan, and India. The insects deposit their wax onto the leaves and twigs of Chinese ash trees; it is scraped off, cleaned with hot water, and cast into molds. It is similar to spermaceti and has been used as a substitute for beeswax, for candles, wax paint, polishing leather, and sizing paper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Chinese insect wax
Chinese was

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A semisolid, waxy material extracted from sebaceous glands of wool-bearing animals, particularly sheep, genus Ovis. It is a complex mixture of 33 high molecular weight alcohols and 36 fatty acids, including cholesterol. One of the unique properties of lanolin is that it can incorporate up to 25-30% water without separation. Since it is readily absorbed by skin, lanolin is used as an emollient in cosmetics, ointments, leather, and as a rust preventative. Lanolin's role in nature is to protect wool and skin of the animal against the environment, also having a role in hygiene.
Gezuiverd en gehydrateerd wolvet.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lanolin
lanoline
