owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemene term die in de houtbranche wordt gebruikt voor stevig hout met een dichte nerfstructuur dat lijkt op echt buxushout, maar afkomstig is van verschillende andere boomsoorten, waaronder Phyllostylon brasiliensis, Tabebuia pentaphylla en verschillende soorten van de geslachten Eucalyptus en Tristania.

General term used by the lumber trade for firm, close-grained woods that resemble true boxwood but are derived from several other species of tree, including Phyllostylon brasiliensis, Tabebuia pentaphylla, and several species in the genera Eucalyptus and Tristania.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: West Indian boxwood
West Indian boxwood (hout)
West Indian boxwood (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Very heavy, hard wood from the species Buxus sempervirens from Eurasia; used for cabinet-making, clarinets, engraving, marquetry, woodturning, tool handles, mallet heads, and as a substitute for ivory.

Zeer zwaar en hard hout van de soort Buxus sempervirens uit Eurazië. Het wordt gebruikt voor de meubelmakerij, klarinetten, graveren, marqueterie, houtdraaien, handvaten van gereedschap, hamerkoppen en ter vervanging van ivoor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: common boxwood (wood)
palmhout
palmhout (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Aesculus indica, veel voorkomend in Himalayaanse laaglanden.
Wood of the species Aesculus indica, common in the Himalayan lowlands.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Indian horse chestnut (wood)
Indische paardenkastanje
Indische paardenkastanje (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood from any of various species producing decorative timber with mottled or banded grain resembling marble.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: marblewood (wood)
marmerhout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemene term voor hout van een van de verschillende soorten bomen of struiken met gestreept sierhout dat wordt gebruikt door meubelmakers.
General term for wood from any of several species of tree or shrub having ornamentally striped wood used by cabinet-makers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: zebra wood (wood)
zebrano
zebrano (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de boom behorende tot het E. gummifera, inheems in Australië. Het hout is roodachtig van kleur en ontleent zijn naam aan de kleur van zijn sap.
Wood from the species Eucalyptus gummifera, used for rough construction, for example, as mining timbers, poles, fences, etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: red bloodwood (wood)
rood bloedhout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Celtis occidentalis; het hout is licht van kleur, geelachtig grijs tot lichtbruin met gele strepen.
Wood of the species Celtis occidentalis; the wood is light-colored, yellowish gray to light brown with yellow streaks.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: common hackberry (wood)
zwepenboom
zwepenboom (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Crataegus monogyna.
Wood of the species Crataegus monogyna.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: common hawthorn (wood)
eenstijlige meidoorn
eenstijlige meidoorn (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material made from glass, having a three-dimensional rectangular form and used architectural building or decorative elements; its function is to admit light while providing visual obscuration.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: glass block

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van het geslacht Oxandra lanceolata uit het noorden van Zuid-Amerika en West-Indië; de belangrijkste bron van commercieel timmerhout van de degamehout-familie. Het heeft een gladde fijne nerf; door de elasticiteit is het zeer geschikt voor het maken van bogen, vishengels, biljartkeus, handvaten van gereedschap, assen van rijtuigen, spaken en kasten.

Wood from the species Oxandra lanceolata from northern South America and the West Indies; the most important commercial timber source of the lancewood family. It has a smooth close grain; its elasticity has made it useful for making bows, fishing rods, billiard cues, tool handles, carriage shafts, wheel spokes, and cabinetry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: echt degamehout
echt degamehout (hout)
true lancewood (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Laurus nobilis die inheems is in het Middellandse Zeegebied; gebruikt voor snufjes, snijwerk en marqueterie.
Wood the species Laurus nobilis native to the Mediterranean region; used for small novelties, carving, and marquetry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bay laurel (wood)
laurier
laurier (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Mahogany having a pattern of curly, flamed, or tiger-striped marks, resembling the pattern seen in wood of violins, which are actually made of various woods other than mahogany.
Mahoniehout met een patroon van golvende, vurige of gestreepte markeringen. Het patroon lijkt op dat in het hout van violen, hoewel die worden gemaakt van andere houtsoorten dan mahoniehout.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fiddle-back mahogany
fiddle-back mahogany

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemene term voor mahoniehout van uitzonderlijk hoge kwaliteit.
General term for any mahogany of particularly high quality.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: baywood
mahoniehout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Strong, even-grained wood from the species Acer campestre, native to Europe, the Balkans, and Turkey. The wood is pale, yellow-brown in color. It has been used for boxes, utensils, furniture, tool handles, musical instruments, boats, wagons, and weapons
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Spaanse aak
Spaanse aak (hout)
field maple (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Quercus laevis.
Wood of the species Quercus laevis.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: American turkey oak
American turkey oak (hout)
American turkey oak (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Quercus michauxii, een waardevolle Noord-Amerikaanse productieboom uit de kustvlakten van de Atlantische Oceaan en de Golf van Mexico, en de Mississippi-vallei; wordt in het Engels 'basket oak' genoemd omdat het hout vaak in repen wordt gezaagd en wordt gebruikt voor het maken van manden.

Wood from the species Quercus michauxii, a valuable North American bottomland timber tree of the Atlantic and Gulf coastal plains and Mississippi Valley region; so-named because the wood is often cut into strips and used for making baskets.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: basket oak
basket oak (hout)
basket oak (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Quercus prinoides.
Wood of the species Quercus prinoides.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dwarf chestnut oak
dwarf chestnut oak (hout)
dwarf chestnut oak (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Quercus imbricaria dat voornamelijk wordt gebruikt voor het maken van shingles en gepotdekselde gevelbeplating van huizen.
Wood of the species Quercus imbricaria, used primarily for making shingles and clapboard siding for houses.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dakspaaneik
dakspaaneik (hout)
shingle oak (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Heavy, black, ebony-like wood of the species Andira aubletii found in Brazil, French Guiana, Guyana, Peru, and Suriname. Used for furniture and valued as highly resistant to insect attack.

Zwaar en zwart ebbenhoutachtig hout van de boomsoort Andira aubletii, die te vinden is in Brazilië, Frans-Guyana, Guyana, Peru en Suriname. Het wordt gebruikt voor meubilair en is waardevol omdat het zeer goed is bestand tegen aantasting door insecten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: acapou
acapou (hout)
acapou (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de boomsoort Aspidosperma peroba; roze van kleur.
Wood obtained from the species Aspidosperma peroba, pink in color.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: peroba rosa
peroba rosa (hout)
red peroba (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de boomsoort Paratecoma peroba; bleekolijfkleurig tot donkerbruin van kleur.
Wood from the species Paratecoma peroba, pale olive to dark brown in color.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: peroba de campos
white peroba (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dense, yellow wood of the species Platanus orientalis, having a fine texture that is similar to maple. It is used for furniture, butcher blocks, chairs, musical instruments, interior finishes, and cabinetry.

Massief geel hout van de boomsoort Platanus orientalis, met een fijne structuur die vergelijkbaar is met esdoornhout. Het wordt gebruikt voor meubels, slagersblokken, stoelen, muziekinstrumenten, interieurafwerkingen en kasten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oosterse plataan
oosterse plataan (hout)
oriental plane (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hard grofkorrelig hout van de boomsoort Platanus racemosa. Het is moeilijk te splijten en te bewerken, maar wordt wel gebruikt voor slagersblokken en voor ander ruw werk.
Tough, coarse-grained wood of the species Platanus racemosa. It is difficult to split and work, but is used for butchers' blocks and for other rough work.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: California sycamore
California sycamore (hout)
California sycamore (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dense, yellow wood of the species Platanus occidentalis, having a fine texture that is similar to maple. It is used for furniture, butcher blocks, chairs, musical instruments, interior finishes, and cabinetry..

Massief geel hout van de soort Platanus occidentalis, met een fijne structuur die vergelijkbaar is met esdoornhout. Het wordt gebruikt voor meubels, slagersblokken, stoelen, muziekinstrumenten, interieurafwerkingen en kasten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: American sycamore (wood)
westerse plataan
westerse plataan (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van bomen van de soort Ficus sycomorus, die inheems is in Afrika ten zuiden van de Sahel en ten noorden van de Steenbokskeerkring. Wordt gebruikt voor meubels en kisten. Gebruik 'sycomorenhout' voor hout van de boomsoort Acer pseudoplatanus en 'westerse plataan' voor hout van de plataansoort Platanus occidentalis.

Wood of trees belonging to the species Ficus sycomorus, native to Africa south of the Sahel and north of the Tropic of Capri. Used for furniture and caskets. For other woods sometimes called simply "sycamore," use "sycamore" for wood from the sycamore maple Acer pseudoplatanus and "American sycamore" for wood from the plane tree species Platanus occidentalis
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sycamore fig (wood)
wilde vijgenboom
wilde vijgenboom (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemene term voor het hout van verschillende bomen, vaak van het genus Populus (populieren).
Common term for the wood of several trees, most in the genus Populus (poplars).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aspen (wood)
espenhout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dense wood of the species Diospyros texana, native to Texas and Oklahoma in the United States, and northeastern Mexico. The sapwood is yellow, while the heartwood found in large trees is ebony black. It is used for furniture and printing blocks, among other purposes.

Massief hout van de soort Diospyros texana, die inheems is in Texas en Oklahoma in de Verenigde Staten en het noordoosten van Mexico. Het spinthout is geel, terwijl het kernhout in grote bomen ebbenhoutzwart is. Het wordt onder meer gebruikt voor meubilair en cliché's.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Texaanse persimmon
Texaanse persimmon (hout)
Texas persimmon (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de boomsoort Diospyros digyna, die inheems is in het oosten van Mexico, Midden-Amerika en in zuidelijke richting tot Colombia. Het hout is geelachtig tot diepgeel met zwarte tekeningen bij het hart van oude stammen; het is compact en geschikt voor schrijnwerk. Meldingen dat donker hout is gebruikt voor meubilair ontstaan waarschijnlijk doordat het wordt verward met andere soorten van het genus Diospyros.

Wood of the species Diospyros digyna, native to eastern Mexico, Central America, and south to Colombia. The wood is yellowish to deep-yellow with black markings near the heart of old trunks; it is compact and suitable for cabinetwork. Reports of dark wood utilized for furniture are probably the result of confusion with other species of the genus Diospyros.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: black persimmon (wood)
zwarte zapote
zwarte zapote (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de boomsoort Schinopsis lorentzii. Het is extreem hard, glanst snel en heeft een gevlekt roodbruin uiterlijk. Het wordt meestal zwart gebeitst. Het hout wordt gebruikt voor houtsnijwerk, spoorbielzen en voor zware constructiedoeleinden.

Wood from the species Schinopsis lorentzii. It is extremely hard, polishes well, and has a spotted reddish brown appearance. It is generally stained black. It is used for carvings, railway sleepers, and heavy construction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: red quebracho
red quebracho (hout)
red quebracho (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Aspidosperma quebracho-blanco. Het is zeer hard, geel van kleur, zwaar en goed bestand tegen buigen en schokken. Als het droogproces niet langzaam verloopt, zal het hout barsten. Het wordt gebruikt voor vloeren, karren, wielen, handvatten van gereedschap, meubels, schaakstukken en ski's. Het wordt soms gebruikt als brandstof, omdat het langzaam verbrandt en daarbij geen vonken of grote hoeveelheden as produceert.

Wood from the species Aspidosperma quebracho-blanco. It is very hard, yellow in color, heavy, and well suited to bending and shock. If the drying process is not slow, the wood will crack. It is used for floors, carts, wheels, tool handles, furniture, chess pieces, and skis. In some places it is used as fuel because it burns slowly and does not produce sparks or large amounts of ash.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: quebracho blanco
quebracho blanco (hout)
white quebracho (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Acidic wood of the species Tieghemella heckelii, reddish to purplish-brown in color, typically with straight grain and dark streaks. It is used for furniture, cabinet work, joinery, decorative veneers, panelling, boat building, flooring, turnery, carving, pianos, and other musical instruments.

Zuurrijk hout van de boomsoort Tieghemella heckelii, dat roodachtig tot paarsachtig bruin van kleur is, meestal met een rechte nerf en donkere strepen. Het wordt gebruikt voor meubilair, schrijnwerk, timmerwerk, decoratief fineer, lambriseringen, scheepsbouw, vloeren, draaiwerk, snijwerk, piano's en andere muziekinstrumenten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: makore (wood)
makoré
makoré (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Correctly, wood from various trees of the genus Jacaranda, native to the West Indies, tropical Americas, Florida, and California. Jacaranda is a fragrant ornamental wood has been used for carvings, small decorative items, pianos, knife handles, cabinets, and expensive furniture. The term is also commonly used as a general term for Jacaranda as well as various varieties of rosewood, which itself is a general term referring to various species of the genera Dalbergia or Melanorrhoea.

Hout van verschillende bomen van het genus Jacaranda, inheems in het Caribisch gebied, het tropische deel van het Amerikaanse continent, Florida en Californië. Jacaranda is een geurig sierhout dat wordt gebruikt voor houtsnijwerk, kleine decoratieve voorwerpen, piano's, heften, kasten en dure meubels. De term wordt ook vaak gebruikt als een algemene term voor het genus Jacaranda en voor verschillende soorten palissanderhout, wat zelf een algemene term is die verwijst naar verschillende soorten van de genera Dalbergia en Melanorrhoea.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: jacaranda
jacaranda (hout)
jacaranda (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemene term voor donker sierhout van diverse bomen uit het tropische deel van Amerika, voornamelijk van het genus Jacaranda, de soorten Dalbergia nigra (Braziliaans palissanderhout) of het genus Peltogyne.
General term for any dark ornamental wood derived from various tropical American trees, especially of the genus Jacaranda, the species Dalbergia nigra (Brazilian rosewood), or the genus Peltogyne.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: palisander (wood)
palissander
palissander (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Brya ebenus die inheems is in Midden-Amerika en de Caribische eilanden. Het komt van zwart of warm bruin kernhout. Het materiaal is bros, zeer zwaar, uitermate hard, heeft een fijne uniforme textuur en kan erg glanzend worden gemaakt. Het wordt gebruikt voor inlegwerk, de rug van borstels, parket en muziekinstrumenten. Het is niet echt palissanderhout.

Wood from the species Brya ebenus native to Central America and the Caribbean islands. It comes from the black or rich brown heartwood. It is brittle, very heavy, exceedingly hard, having a fine uniform texture, and capable of receiving a high polish. It is used for inlays, brush backs, parquet, and musical instruments. Not a true rosewood.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cocushout
cocushout (hout)
cocuswood (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout dat wordt verkregen van de boomsoort Dalbergia sissoo, die inheems is in het Indiase subcontinent. Het kernhout is donkerbruin en slijtvast; het spinthout is lichter van kleur en gevoelig voor aantasting door schimmels en borende insecten. Het hout wordt gebruikt voor verfijnd kastwerk, fineer, vloeren, triplex, landbouwwerktuigen, muziekinstrumenten, houtsnijwerk, ski's en boten.

Wood derived from the species Dalbergia sissoo, native to the Indian subcontinent. The heartwood is dark brown and durable; the sapwood is lighter in color and prone attack by fungi and borers. The wood is used for the finest cabinetry, veneer, flooring, plywood, agricultural tools, musical instruments, carvings, skis, and boats.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: shisham
shisham (hout)
shisham (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Chloroxylon swietenia, inheems in Zuidoost-Azië, India en Sri Lanka. Het is glanzend, goudkleurig hout dat wordt gebruikt voor fijn schrijnwerk, fineer en landbouwwerktuigen.
Wood of the species Chloroxylon swietenia, native to southeast Asia, India, and Sri Lanka. It is a silky, golden-colored wood used for fine cabinetwork, veneer, and farming tools.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Ceylon satijnhout
Ceylon satijnhout (hout)
Ceylon satinwood (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Glanzend donkergeel hout van de soort Zanthoxylum flavum, die inheems is in Zuid-Amerika, de Caribische eilanden en Afrika. Dit olieachtige timmerhout heeft een dichte, onregelmatige nerf, ruikt naar kokosnoot en kan sterk glanzend worden gemaakt.

Lustrous, dark yellow wood from the species Zanthoxylum flavum, native to South America, the Caribbean islands, and Africa. This oily timber has a close, irregular grain, smells like coconut, and polishes to a high gloss.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: West Indian satinwood (wood)
West-Indisch satijnhout
West-Indisch satijnhout (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil extracted from the root bark sassafras trees, native to North America and Asia. Sassafras oil is used as an odorant in fabrics, a flavorant, and an ingredient in soaps and medicine.

Olie die wordt gewonnen uit de wortelschors van sassafrasbomen, inheems in Noord-Amerika en Azië. Sassafrasolie wordt gebruikt als geurstof in weefsels, als smaakstof en als ingrediënt van zeep en medicijnen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sassafras oil
sassafrasolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Soft, fine-grained wood of the species Liriodendron tulipifera of North America. The sapwood is usually a creamy off-white color; heartwood is pale green, often with streaks of red, purple, or black. It is cheap, easy-to-work, can take a sharp edge, and is stable, used to seal pipes and valves in organs, for siding clapboards, coffin boxes, pattern timber, and wooden ware.

Zacht hout met een fijne nerf van de soort Liriodendron tulipifera uit Noord-Amerika. Het spinthout is meestal roomachtig gebroken wit; het kernhout is bleekgroen, vaak met rode, paarse of zwarte strepen. Het is goedkoop, eenvoudig te bewerken, kan scherp worden gemaakt en is stabiel. Het wordt gebruikt om pijpen en kleppen van orgels af te dichten, voor dakspanen, doodskisten, gemodelleerd hout en houtwaren.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: American tulipwood (wood)
tulpenboomhout
tulpenboomhout (hout)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Bleekgroene etherische olie die wordt verkregen uit de schillen van limoenen. Limoenolie wordt meestal bereid door stoomdestillatie; de bestanddelen zijn limoneen en citral. de olie wordt gebruikt in smaakstof, parfums, insecticiden, ontsmettingsmiddelen, reinigingsproducten, aromatherapie en als bron van vitamine C.

Pale green, volatile oil obtained from the rinds of the lime fruit. Lime oil is normally prepared by steam distillation; its components are limonene and citral. It is used in flavoring, perfumes, insecticide, antiseptic, cleaning products, aromatherapy, and as a source of vitamin C.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lime oil
limoenolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Essential oil obtained from the rind of the orange and used in perfume, as flavoring, in herbal medicine, cleaning products, insecticide, and as an appetite suppressant.
Etherische olie die wordt verkregen uit de schil van de sinaasappel en wordt gebruikt in parfum, als smaakstof, in de kruidengeneeskunde, in reinigingsproducten en insecticiden, en als eetlustremmer.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: orange oil
sinaasappelolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de soort Quercus virginiana, die inheems is in het zuidoostelijke kustgebied van de Verenigde Staten tot in Mexico en Cuba. Het is de hardste soort van alle Amerikaanse eiken. Het wordt gebruikt voor de bouw van schepen, wagons en landbouwwerktuigen. In de scheepsbouw werd het hout het meest gebruikt vanwege zijn weerstand tegen zout water en omdat het niet snel ging rotten. Het werd in de jaren negentig van de 18e eeuw gebruikt voor de bouw van het beroemde zeilschip USS Constitution, dat de bijnaam Old Ironsides had.

Wood of the species Quercus virginiana, native to the southeastern and gulf area of the United States into Mexico, and Cuba. It is the hardest of all American oaks. It is used in the construction of ships, wagons, and farm implements. Favored for shipbuilding because of its tolerance for salt water and its resistance to decay, it was famously used to build the USS Constitution sailing ship, nicknamed Old Ironsides, in the 1790s.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: southern live oak
southern live oak (hout)
southern live oak (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pale reddish brown wood of the species Quercus rubra, having sapwood that is dark, heavy, hard, strong, and coarse-grained. It cracks in drying, but is treated and used for furniture, construction, and the interior of houses.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Amerikaans eikenhout
northern red oak (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to a white lead-glazed 'faïence fine' introduced by Jacques Chambrette at Lunéville in 1748 and there used unglazed for biscuit figures and groups and as a pipe clay.

Verwijst naar een 'faïence fine' met wit loodglazuur, in 1748 geïntroduceerd door Jacques Chambrette in Luneville, waar het ongeglazuurd werd gebruikt voor biscuitfiguren en -groepen en als klei voor pijpen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: terre de Lorraine
terre de Lorraine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gom dat wordt geproduceerd door de zaden van de johannesbroodboom te vermalen tot een fijn poeder, die oplost in warm water en afkoelt tot een stabiele gel die uitstekend is geschikt om folie mee te maken. De gom wordt gebruikt als verdikkingsmiddel voor verfstof en als appret voor voedsel, cosmetica, textiel en papier. Johannesbroodpitmeel is aangetroffen in de windselen van Egyptische mummies.

Gum produced from grinding the seeds of the carob tree to a fine powder, which dissolves in hot water and cools to form a stable gel that is an excellent film former. The gum is used as dye thickener, and as size for food, cosmetics, textiles, and paper. Locust bean gums have been detected in the wrappings of Egyptian mummies.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: johannesbroodgom
locust bean gum

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Fragrant myrrhlike oleoresin obtained from the small evergreen tree, Commiphora opobalsamum, native to the Middle East. Used in perfumes and medicines. Referred to in biblical Genesis as a healing balm; valued in medicine and perfume in ancient Greece and the Roman Empire. The term "balm of Gilead" has been incorrectly used to refer to "Canada balsam," which is derived from a North American tree.

Geurige mirreachtige oliehoudende hars die wordt verkregen uit de kleine groenblijvende boom Commiphora opobalsamum, die inheems is in het Midden-Oosten. Wordt gebruikt in parfums en medicijnen. In het Bijbelboek Genesis wordt ernaar verwezen als een genezende balsem. In het oude Griekenland en het Romeinse Rijk werd het beschouwd als een waardevol medicijn en parfum. De term 'ontariopopulierenhars' wordt soms onterecht gebruikt om te verwijzen naar 'canadabalsem', die afkomstig is van een Noord-Amerikaanse boom.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Ontariopopulierenhars
balm of Gilead

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: De ruwe balsem van de Franse zeeden Pinus pinaster. Wordt gebruikt voor de productie van het gedestilleerde 'Burgundy turpentine' en van 'Burgundy pitch', dat niet is gedestilleerd.
The raw balsam of the French Maritime pine tree, Pinus pinaster. It is used to produce the distilled "Burgundy turpentine" and "Burgundy pitch," which is not distilled.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Bordeaux turpentine
Bordeaux turpentine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sticky, viscous yellow sap obtained from conifers. The crude turpentine contains about 65 percent rosin (solid residue) and 18 percent oil of turpentine (volatile portion). It is distilled to create the volatile oil of turpentine, usually shortened to "turpentine (oil)."

Een kleverig en stroperig geel sap dat wordt verkregen uit naaldbomen. De ruwe terpentijn bevat ongeveer 65% hars (vast residu) en 18% olie van terpentijn (vluchtig gedeelte). Terpentijn wordt gedistilleerd voor het produceren van vluchtige terpentijnolie, meestal afgekort tot 'terpentijn (olie)'.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: terpentijn
terpentijn (hars)
turpentine (resin)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A brown, sticky, aromatic resin obtained from trees of the genus Liquidambar, including L. orientalis, native to Turkey. A white solid powder that forms in the steam distillate obtained from storax is polystyrene. Storax resin is sometimes used as a mounting media for microscope slides. For the a brown, aromatic resin obtained from the genus Styrax, use "benzoin." Resins from both Sytrax and Liquidambar trees were formerly called "storax," but "storax" is no longer used for resin of genus Styrax.

Een bruin, kleverig, aromatisch hars dat wordt verkregen uit bomen van het genus Liquidambar, waaronder de L. orientalis uit Turkije. In het stoomdistillaat van storax wordt het witte vaste poeder polystyreen gevormd. Storaxhars wordt soms gebruikt voor het bevestigen van microscoopglaasjes. Gebruik 'benzoë' voor een bruine, aromatische hars die wordt verkregen uit het geslacht Styrax. Vroeger werden de harsen van zowel de Styrax als de Liquidambar 'storax' genoemd, maar inmiddels wordt 'storax' niet meer gebruikt voor hars van het geslacht Styrax.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: storax
storax (hars)
storax (resin)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Asfalt dat wordt aangetroffen in natuurlijke afzettingen, in tegenstelling tot asfalt dat wordt gevormd als een residu na de distillatie van petroleum. Natuurlijk asfalt ontstaat waar ruwe olie uit de grond komt. Het wordt in een vroeg stadium gevormd bij de afbraak van organische mariene afzettingen in petroleum. Het bevat meestal mineralen, in tegenstelling tot residuaal petroleumasfalt (hoewel mineralen wel kunnen worden toegevoegd).

Asphalt found in natural deposits, as distinguished from asphalt formed as a residue from the distillation of petroleum. Natural asphalt is found where crude oil seeps from the ground. It was formed during an early stage in the breakdown of organic marine deposits into petroleum. It characteristically contains minerals, while residual petroleum asphalt does not (although minerals may be added).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: natural asphalt
natuurlijk asfalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dark brown or black solid to semisolid material that is the organic, or hydrocarbon, portion of asphalt. It was used in ancient times as a sealant, for example in ancient Egypt. It is currently is used in hot-melt adhesives, coating, paints, sealants, roofing, and road coating.

Donkerbruine of zwarte vaste tot halfvaste stof, het organische of koolwaterstofhoudende deel van asfalt. Het werd in de oudheid gebruikt als een dichtingsproduct, bijvoorbeeld in het oude Egypte. Het wordt momenteel gebruikt in smeltlijmen, coatings, verven, dichtingsproducten, dakbedekking en straatbedekking.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: asfaltbitumen
asphaltic bitumen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Cutback asphalt that has the adition of kerosene, which is less volatile than other additives, causing a slower evaporation process.
Cutbackasfalt waaraan kerosine is toegevoegd. Dit is minder vluchtig dan andere additieven waardoor het verdampingsproces langer duurt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: medium-curing asphalt
medium-curing asphalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Asfaltmengsel met een additief voor het vloeibaar maken van het materiaal, zodat het eenvoudiger kan worden gemengd en aangebracht.
Asphalt mixture that includes and additive to liquify the material for easier blending and applicaiton.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cutback asphalt
cutback asphalt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A strongly alkaline cleaner having the primary ingredients sodium carbonate and sodium bicarbonate, used in textile processing and commercial laundry soaps. Such an alkaline soap causes cottons to yellow.

Een sterk alkalisch schoonmaakmiddel met als belangrijkste ingrediënten natriumcarbonaat en natriumbicarbonaat, dat wordt gebruikt voor textielverwerking en waspoeders. Katoen wordt geel van een dergelijke alkalische zeep.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: laundry soda
laundry soda

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Water dat via leidingen naar kranen in een woning of een ander gebouw wordt geleid. Door zijn niet-corrosieve eigenschappen is leidingwater beter dan gedistilleerd water geschikt voor de conservering van oude stenen materialen.

Water drawn through taps from pipes in a dwelling or other structure. Due to its noncorrosive properties, tap water may be used in conservation of ancient stone materials in preference to distilled water.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: leidingwater
tap water

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sodium dithionite (also known as sodium hydrosulfite) is a reductive bleaching chemical. Usage includes iron stain removal, and occasionally to treat corroded copper and silver artifacts in object conservation. It can also be used for purification of water and gas and as a sulfonating agent or a sodium ion source in industrial processes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium dithionite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hars dat wordt gewonnen op het Griekse eiland Chios en dat bekendstaat om zijn hoge kwaliteit.
The resin collected from the Greek island of Chios, having the reputation for the highest quality.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Chios mastic
mastiek

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hars dat wordt gewonnen in India.
The resin collected in India.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Bombay mastic
Mastic Bombay

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemene term voor materialen die worden verkregen uit de afscheiding van bepaalde bomen of struiken. Natuurlijke harsen zijn aromatische koolwaterstoffen die doorgaans oplosbaar zijn in alcohol of terpentijn en niet in water.
General term for materials obtained from excretions from certain trees or shrubs. Natural resins are aromatic hydrocarbons that are generally soluble in alcohol or turpentine and insoluble in water.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: natural resin
natuurhars

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hars met een polymere structuur dat wordt gevormd door een chemische reactie tussen twee of meer stoffen. Het wordt vooral gebruikt in kunststoffen.
Resin having a polymeric structure, that is, formed by a chemical reaction between two or more substances; used chiefly in plastics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: synthetic resin
synthetic resin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A yellow earth mineral that occurs naturally as an opaque crystalline material, primarily composed of iron hydroxide and varying in color from red to yellowish-brown. It is used for pigment and large clumps have also been carved for small ornamental items.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: goethite (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: General term for greenstone found on South Island, New Zealand. The term refers to any of three different types of stone: nephrite, bowenite, and serpentinite. Maori do not classify pounamu by geological origin, but by appearance according to color, markings, and translucency. There are many local names for different pounamu, but four main varieties are widely recognized: inanga, kahurangi, kawakawa, and tangiwai.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pounamu

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Maori pounamu stone that is paler than other varieties, often of a pearly-white or gray-green nephrite, ranging from translucent to opaque. It can change color over time, developing a light-olive tint as it ages and oxidizes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: inanga (stone)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rarest variety of Maori pounamu stone; usually a variety of nephrite, it is highly translucent and often comes in vivid shades of green.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: kahurangi (stone)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The most common variety of Maori pounamu stone that comes in many shades, from strong rich green to dark green; often a translucent nephrite. It is often characterized by small dark inclusions, which is considered an addition to its character.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: kawakawa (stone)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Variety of Maori pounamu stone that is clear like glass, and ranges in color from olive-green to bluish-green. It is the stone used earliest as pounamu. The composition is typically bowenite rather than nephrite. Most tangiwai is comes from two isolated areas at Piopiotahi (Milford Sound).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tangiwai (stone)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A thin layer of gold or other metal that has been applied as a decorative surface finish, whether the metal was applied as a thin leaf, by electroplating, or as a thin paint layer. Examples of gilding include that applications on paintings, furniture, frames, sculptures, and the edges of pages of books.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gilding (material)
verguldsel

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A combination of wax and resin used as a preservative, adhesive, and in thermal transfer technologies. In the conservation of paintings, it has been used reinforce works by applying a paper or fabric lining attached with a wax-resin.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: wax-resin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Eroded matter from preexisting rocks which is carried and deposited by water, wind, or ice, forming layers on the Earth's surface and fluvial deposits. Sedimentary rock.is composed of consolidated sediment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sediment

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Microscopic fossilized remains of organisms usually less than 2mm in size. Subject studied by micropaleontology.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: microfossils

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Fossilized fecal material; indirect evidence of prehistoric life, particularly as pertains to ancient diet.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: coprolites

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Coarse grained, veined marble ranging in color from white to salmon-pink, quarried in and around Candoglia, Piedmont, Italy. It is primarily known as the building material used for Milan Cathedral.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Candoglia marble

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Polymerized methyl methacrylate is a compound having a hard and glasslike appearance, with softening temperature from 105-125 C. Classified as bioinert. As a resin, widely used as a glass substitute (e.g., Plexiglass (TM)) and a bonelike material for prosthetics. First commercially sold in 1933 as a glass substitute.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polymethyl methacrylate (polyacrylate)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: All sediment particles, regardless of mineral origin, that fall within a specified size range between those of sand and clay. An unconsolidated aggregation of particles is also called silt; a consolidated aggregate, silt-stone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: In physics, plasma is an electrically conductive gas of low density, affected by magnetic fields. It is fully ionized and contains approximately equal numbers of positive and negative ions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plasma

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A synthetic wax made by catalytic polymerization of low molecular weight, high-density ethylene. It may be used as a reversible protective coating in many applications including the conservation of outdoor sculpture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyethylene wax

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Soluble salts are dissolved minerals whose crystallization on the surface and in the substrate of materials causes efflorescence and deterioration.The presence of water-soluble salts is a key factor in the degradation of masonry and other highly porous stone building materials. Surface efflorescence is a serious threat to ancient mural paintings. Conservation seeks to identify soluble salts in objects affected, and extract them or otherwise halt the degradation they inflict.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: soluble salt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An inductively coupled plasma (ICP) is a type of high-temperature plasma (ionized gas) source generated by electric currents produced by electromagnetic induction. It is used to determine elemental content of materials in ICP spectrometry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: inductively coupled plasma

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Strontium (symbol: Sr) is a soft silver-white metallic element that turns yellow when exposed to air. Strontium is used commercially in luminous paint, fireworks and television tubes, and the compound strontium-oxide serves as a non-toxic replacement for lead in ceramic glazes. Paleontologists study strontium levels in human and animal bone for information about ancient diet.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: strontium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: In an archaeological context, analysis of stable strontium isotopes in ancient objects and materials can supply information about date and provenance. Strontium in its isotopic form.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: strontium isotopes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to any methylated derivative of cellulose. Methyl cellulose is a white powder that swells in water and is used as a substitute for natural gums, functioning in various commercial contexts as emulsifying, thickening, or sizing agent, lubricant, and suspension aid. In textile and paper conservation, it is used as an adhesive and as a poulticing material for removal of stains.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: methyl cellulose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A salt of oxalic acid, calcium oxalate can form naturally on calcareous stones as a reaction to oxalic acid excretions of mosses and lichens. In a conservation context, calcium oxalate is generally considered in its role as a form of bioterioration but its cultivation as a protective film for limestone surfaces has been investigated as well.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium oxalate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A salt or ester of oxalic acid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oxalate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Nonmetallic chemical element (H). It is a colorless, odorless, tasteless gas, the lightest chemical element, and is used in rocket fuels and balloons. Its most important compound (with oxygen) is water.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydrogen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Fossiliferous limestone composed of coral and shell and oolite particles or debris from erosion of older limestones. Calcarenites have been used as a building and ornamental stone, especially in the Apulia region of South Eastern Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcarenite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to a carbonate of ammonium commonly known as hartshorn. It is a white powder used in smelling salts, baking powder, textile dyeing, and other applications. In conservation, a solution of ammonium carbonate is used as a solubilizing agent for extraction of soluble salts present on deteriorated stone surfaces.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ammonium carbonate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Plant trace fossils, microscopic mineral particles secreted by plants which are highly resistant to deterioration. Phytoliths can be a source of important palaeobotanical information.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: phytoliths

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Used in an ecological context to describe a large class of nitrogen oxide gases produced in combustion which occur as atmospheric pollutants. Colorless, poisonous gas formed when nitric acid reacts with copper or when ammonia reacts with platinum. It is produced in combustion engine processes such as automobile emissions, resulting in acid rain and photochemical smog. It is also an important messenger molecule in mammals and other animals, produced through cellular metabolism, and involved in oxygen transmission, blood pressure regulation, and other physiological activities.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nitrogen oxides

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Stable oxygen atoms that have the same atomic number as the element oxygen, but differ in atomic weight. O-17 and O-18 are examples of stable oxygen isotopes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oxygen isotopes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Isotopes of nitrogen: nitrogen-14 and the uncommon isotope, nitrogen-15.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nitrogen isotopes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Isotopes of lead; examples of use are for medical and scientific purposes and also a target in the production of super heavy elements.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lead isotopes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pure metallic element having as symbol Bi. Bismuth is brittle with a low melting point; a grayish-white lustrous metal oxidized by air. It is chiefly used in the arts as an alloy, as in bronze, and is used ground as a pigment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bismuth

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A large and varied class of crystalline metal aluminosilicate minerals containing loosely held water molecules. They are often found in the cavities of igneous rocks. Specialized zeolite matrices can be prepared by varying heat and pressure to aluminum oxide and silicon dioxide. Zeolites have numerous technical applications; e.g., as ion exhange resins, absorbents, or molecular sieves.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: zeolite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Modified nylon developed by DuPont in the 1940's; formerly used in conservation as an adhesive and sizing agent for fragile paper, and as a consolidant for stone and friable pigments. Its use was discontinued following the discovery that over time it becomes insoluble and opaque, and is unsafe to remove.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: soluble nylon

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A toxic and reactive reddish gas, NO2, nitrogen dioxide is an atmospheric pollutant (as in photochemical smog) produced by combustion of fossil fuels. Exposure to nitrogen oxide can cause fading of dyes and organic colorants in paints, textiles, and photographs, as well as deterioration of calcareous stone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nitrogen dioxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pure metallic element having symbol TH and atomic number 90; a radioactive, soft, silvery metal most often extracted from the phosphate mineral, monazite. Use also for this metal as processed and formed, usually in combination with other substances, to make various objects and materials.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: thorium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An ester or salt of phosphoric acid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: phosphate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Compound formed by interaction of free calcium and phosphate. Calcium phosphate is a component of bone and tooth enamel and the chief source of calcium in bovine milk.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium phosphate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of the salts of magnesium and phosphate, which may appear in monobasic, dibasic, or tribasic form. Deposits of magnesium phosphates bobierrite, newberyte and struvite are found in ivory artifacts and excavated mammoth and elephant tusks.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: magnesium phosphate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A complex calcium phosphate, a naturally occuring mineral form of calcium apatite, that serves as an important component of tooth enamel and vertebrate bone. In an archaeological context, hydroxyapatite from human and animal remains is studied to reconstruct ancient diet.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydroxyapatite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A class of volcanic rocks, light in color and density, chiefly composed of alkali feldspar in which a small amount of quartz or oligoclase may also be present.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: trachyte

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A silver ore, also known as argentite, acanthite, and silver glance, used in niello work and as a colorant in ceramic glazes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silver sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Magnetite that possesses polarity. Lodestones, or natural magnets, have been found in Siberia, the Island of Elba, and in Arkansas.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lodestone

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A glass-forming soluble silicate salt with many applications. In conservation, potassium silicate in solution has been applied, for example, as a consolidant for fragile stone and earthen structures and as a binder for the pictorial reintegration of outdoor mural paintings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: potassium silicate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A honey-brown calcareous sandstone quarried in Fiesole and other locations in the vicinity of Florence, where it is used as a building stone. The Ponte Vecchio, Pitti Palace, and Palazzo Vecchio are all pietraforte constructions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietraforte

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A creamy white or golden colored limestone dating from the Miocene period that is quarried in Lecce, a city in the Salento region of South East Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra di Lecce

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Porous, fossiliferous limestone, yellowish white in color, quarried near Verona, Italy; used as a construction material.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra di Vicenza

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A fine grain dolomitic limestone, yellow, white, or pink in color, quarried along the eastern shore of Lago Maggiore near Angera in the Lombardy region of northern Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Angera stone

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A durable, fossiliferous limestone quarried near Verona, Italy; used as a building material since ancient times.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra di Prun

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Calcareous tufa stone used for building and sculptural decoration originating in quarries near the town of Mendicino in Calabria, Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra di Mendicino

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Beige colored limestone used as a building and construction material quarried near town of San Lucido in province of Cosenza, Calabria, Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra di San Lucido

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to several groups of greenschist found in the Italian Central Alps which contain carvable soapstone; much used in the Middle Ages as a material for the production of food preparation and storage vessels, and of stoves.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra ollare

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Bluish sandstone used as a building material; quarried near the towns of Oggiono and Sirone in Lombardy, Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra d'Oggiono

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An easily worked yellow-brown fossiliferous limestone quarried in the Berici Hills south of Vicenza. It has been used since ancient times as a building and ornamental stone; the cathedral of Padua is a pietra di Nanto construction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra di Nanto

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A red colored limestone quarried near Verona, Italy from the "Rosso Ammonitico Veronese" formation; used as a construction material in buildings and monuments.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pietra di Verona

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Solid carbon dioxide; used as a refrigerant. In the conservation science dry ice is sometimes used for cryogenic blasting of objects.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dry ice

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A water-soluble polymer, commonly known as carboxymethylcellulose (CMC), composed of the sodium salt of modified cellulose. A viscous gel when dispersed in water at low concentrations, CMC forms a tough, non-soluble film in reaction with heavy metal salts. In conservation, it is used as an adhesive and as a poultice for cleaning stone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium carboxymethyl cellulose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Matreial made of thermoplastic polymer or copolymer of ethylene, forming a durable, lightweight, resilient, closed-cell material. Often used for packaging fragile goods due to its excellent vibration dampening and insulation properties. It also offers high resistance to chemicals and moisture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyethylene foam

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sodium compound which in its anhydrous form occurs in nature as a chemical precipitate found in the minerals thenardite and mirabilite. It may also be obtained synthetically by mixing sodium chloride and sulfuric acid. As a solid or powder, sodium sulphate is used in the manufacture of various products. In conservation science it is addressed as an agent of salt damage to stone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium sulfate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hydrous sodium carbonate found in nature as evaporative residues. Used widely as a silica source in early glass manufacture; in ancient Egypt used as well as a bleach for linen, a preservative in mummification, and as an ingredient of incense.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: natron

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: White crystalline salt that occurs in nature as the mineral magnesite and may be prepared artificially by precipitation. It is used in pigments, inks, glass, ceramic glazes, and dentifrice. Magnesium carbonate has also been used as a sorbent powder for water-free (dry) cleaning of jewelry, doll hair, and other items. Aqueous solutions of magnesium carbonate are used for neutralization and alkalization of paper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: magnesium carbonate (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to the calcium salt of phytic acid. In conservation, used in a solution to inhibit iron gall corrosion on manuscripts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium phytate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hydroxypropyl cellulose (HPC) is a water-soluble cellulose ether used as an emulsifier, thickener, and suspending agent in many types of solutions. In conservation, HPC is used as a consolidant for leather afflicted by "red rot", and as a fixative for pigments and dyes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydroxypropyl cellulose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Limonite refers to any hydrated iron ore. A brownish yellow deposit, it is formed by precipitation in marshy areas and is found mixed in clay and sand as loose powder or as a mass. Limonite is also called bog iron ore.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: limonite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any compound joining fluorine to another element or to an organic group.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fluoride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A mineral composed of aluminum sulfate and hydrous basic calcium often formed by the reaction of sulfates and concrete or mortar. Ettringite crystal formation induces sulfate decay in the cement paste matrix. Conservation interventions seek to remove ettringite or limit its attack.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ettringite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: White, water soluble crystalline or granular powder, commonly known as baking soda or bicarbonate of soda. It is used as a leavening agent for baking; in medicine as an antacid; as a whitening agent in toothpastes; a fire retardant; a stain-absorbing ingredient in dry cleaning preparations. Chemical formula: NaHC03.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium bicarbonate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to any rock or mineral from which iron can be extracted.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: iron ore

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to hard cast steel made by various techniques, all of which involve heating of materials in crucibles. Modern equipment, such as the electric arc furnace, has made these methods obsolete.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: crucible steel

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Chlorine compound commonly used as a bleaching agent for textiles and paper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium chlorite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Paratacamite is a basic chloride of copper sometimes used as a green pigment in painting. In a conservation context, its presence as a deposit on bronze and copper artifacts indicates bronze disease.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: paratacamite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Traditional Japanese alloy of copper and gold. It is often subjected to a chemical process that produces a blue-black patina. Shakudo has historically been used for ornamental fittings as on katana.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: shakudo

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A traditional crucible steel of southern India used for wire and sharp edged tools. Although associated in the popular imagination with Damascene swords, and legendarily a supersteel, wootz has a brittle structure subject to shattering, making it more suitable for ceremonial blades than for actual use in battle.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: wootz

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Broadly refers to any sulfide of copper, more specifically to the blackish crystalline sulfide CuS used in textile dyeing and as a black pigment in ancient painting. The presence of copper sulfide on the surface of ancient bronze artifacts has generated much debate over whether it should be seen as symptomatic of copper corrosion or as an intentional patination technique.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: copper sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any enzyme which splits triglyceride fats into their component fatty acids and glycerol. Lipase, found in the body, aids in the digestion of food. Lipase, added to detergents, aids cleaning. In conservation, lipase is sometimes used for removal of oil-based varnishes from paintings and of oil stains from drawings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lipase

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Zirconium is a metallic element having symbol Zr and atomic weight 91.22. It is obtained from zircon and other minerals and is commercially the most important ore. A hard metal resistant to heat and corrosion, it is much used in nuclear reactors, in alloys, refractories, and ceramics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: zirconium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A hard, crystalline solid solution of carbon in iron, martensite is the chief constituent of hardened steel. It is a decomposition product of austenite formed by rapid quenching from high temperatures.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: martensite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Digestive enzyme that breaks down starch by hydrolysis into its basic sugars. In conservation, used for removal of starch adhesives.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: amylase

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white, amorphous mineral composed of silicate, carbonate, and calcium sulfate. It is often formed by the reaction of sulfates and concrete or mortar. Thaumasite crystal formation induces sulfate decay in the cement paste matrix. Conservation interventions seek to remove thaumasite or limit its attack.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: thaumasite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Chitosan is the deacetylated form of chitin, the chief component in the exoskeletons of crustaceans, insects, and beetles. It is used in horticulture and agriculture as a biopesticide, and plant growth enhancer; and in medicine as a coagulant. As a sprayed coating, cyanoethylated chitosan is used to protect historic paper material. Chitosan is also found as an organic component incorporated into polymer materials to form a self-healing coating which promises to render the painted surfaces it is applied to scratch-free.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: chitosan

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to hydrophobic silane used as coating on stone or concrete to repel water.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: alkylalkoxysilane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A chemical compound; in conservation, a chelating agent of ammonium salt of citric acid used in solution for surface cleaning of paper, paintings, and other materials. May also be used as a buffering agent, preservative, and food additive.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: triammonium citrate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A granitoid rock found in southern India used as a material in local construction and sculpture. Named (by T.L. Walker in 1902) after regional tribe, the Konds.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: khondalite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Generic name for any of a class of compounds formerly used as a fire-extinguishing agent. When exposed to flame, these chlorofluorocarbon gases release halogen atoms which interact with hydrogen atoms, suppressing combustion in the process. They also deplete the earth's ozone when exposed to solar ultraviolet light and have consequently been withdrawn from use. Included in the group are Halon: dichlorodifluoromethane, CCl2F2; Halon 1211: bromochlorodifluoromethane, CBrClF2; and Halon 1301: trifluorobromomethane, CBrF3.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: halon

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of a class of low molecular-weight synthetic varnish resins, also known as ketone resins, composed of polymerized cyclohexanone and/or methyl cyclohexanone and widely used for picture varnishes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polycyclohexanone

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to oxalate with ammonia commercially produced as colorless crystals used for dyeing textiles and in other applications. In conservation, ammonium oxalate in solution is used as a treatment for calcium carbonate based surfaces (such as limestones, marbles, historical wall paintings). It forms a protective layer of calcium oxalate on surfaces through chemical reaction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ammonium oxalate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gold applied over a silver object using the fire-gilding method or by electrolysis.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silver gilding

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A particular type of breccia marble, composed of fragments of rocks of several different colors, found in Provence, France.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: brèche d'Alep

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: New World hardwood derived from several species of the Swartzia genus, having a dark reddish brown, purplish, or nearly black heartwood and pale yellowish white sapwood that is sharply demarcated.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: wamara (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white, medium-grain marble composed of greater than 90% calcium magnesium carbonate. Dolomitic marbles were quarried in Cape Vathy on Thasos from antiquity to about the 5th century CE.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dolomitic marble

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pure metallic element having symbol MO and atomic number 42; a gray silvery metal. Use also for this metal as processed and formed, usually in combination with other substances, to make objects and materials.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: molybdenum

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pure metallic element having symbol Ir and atomic number 77; a hard, brittle silvery-white metal of the platinum family. Iridium is the most corrosion-resistant metal and the second densest chemical element.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: iridium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Monosulfide of iron found in nature as pyrrhotite and troilite. It is synthesized to use in generating hydrogen sulfide.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ferrous sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pure metallic element having symbol Rb and atomic number 37; soft, silvery white, and very reactive, rubidium is found as a trace constituent of various alkali minerals. It is used in photoelectric cells and as a catalyst.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rubidium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Silane used as a crosslinking agent of silicone rubber and a coupling agent of glass fiber and treatment agents of reinforced plastic laminated product. It is also used as a consolidant in combination with Paraloid B-72 (TM) acrylic resin to treat deteriorated limestones, sandstones, and marbles.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: methyltrimethoxysilane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Toxic, flammable, colorless gas that smells like rotten eggs. Hydrogen sulfide may be created by decay of organic matter or obtained as a byproduct of refining carbonaceous fuels such as natural gas, crude oil, and coal. As an atmospheric pollutant, hydrogen sulfide blackens lead pigments, and tarnishes silver.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydrogen sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood of the Thuja plicata species, having a reddish to dull brown heartwood with a faint, sweetish odor. The wood is used for shingles, boat making, and other purposes for which resistance to moisture, decay, and insect damage is important.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: western red cedar (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Naturally occurring lipid found in plants and animals, triglyceride is a chemical compound in which three molecules of a fatty acid are united by oxygen to one molecule of glycerol. Triglycerides function as stores of energy and are the chief components in most animal and vegetable fats and oils. Triglycerides are named according to fatty acid components, e.g. stearin is the triglyceride of stearic acid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: triglyceride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A double salt of sodium bicarbonate and sodium carbonate, forming in white crystalline needles. It is used in the treatment of water for softening or cleaning applications. In conservation, used in solution to stabilize corrosion by removing chlorides and other salts from iron and bronze.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium sesquicarbonate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aromatic, yellow gum resin obtained from various African, Arabian, and Indian trees of the Commiphora genus. Myrrh contains approximately 25% resin (mostly triterpenoids), 60% gum, and 15% volatile oils. Translucent yellow resins have been used for incense and perfumes since ancient times. Myrrh has also been used for its healing properties in traditional medicines.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: myrrh

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pure metallic element having symbol Li and atomic number 3; a soft, silver-white metal, the lightest element in the alkali metal series. It is obtained from minerals, such as spodumene, in which it occurs or as a byproduct of potash and borax. Use also for this metal as processed and formed for use as a heat transfer medium in nuclear reactors or as a strengthener in alloys and many manufactured products such as ceramics and glass. Its salt is used in psychiatric medications.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lithium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic polymer of the polyester family made by condensing ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid. It is used to make textile fibers, disposable beverage bottles, photographic film, and magnetic recording tape. Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) was the first commercially marketed polyester, sold as Dacron (TM) in the U.S.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyethylene terephthalate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A composite material whose grain size is measured in nanometers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nanocomposite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A nonmetallic element of the halogen family with atomic number 53 and symbol I. It is a dark crystalline solid used as an additive to salt to prevent iodine insufficiency and is used in dyes, photographic film, x-ray contrast media, and other applications.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: iodine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A type of glass manufactured by German-American John Frederick Amelung’s New Bremen Glass Manufactory in Maryland, U.S. between 1784 and ca. 1795. Amelung brought over German craftsmen and sought financial support from German and American businessmen and the U.S. government in establishing a permanent crafts community. His industry failed after the U.S. Congress rejected Amelung’s request for a loan in 1790. Our understanding of the technique and style of this glass is largely speculative and fragmentary as few examples survive.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Amelung glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A resin extracted from birch bark. It has been identified as a component of archaeological tars found in Austrian sites, demonstrating that the Iron Age tars were made from birch.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: betulin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Semi-metallic element having symbol Ge and atomic number 32. A silvery gray metalloid, germanium occurs in sulfide ores and is used as a semiconductor, in alloys, and in the manufacture of infrared transmitting glass.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: germanium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood of the Chamaecyparis obtusa tree, an evergreen native to Japan and East Asia. Wood is reddish-brown, fragrant, durable and fine grain. It is used for Shinto and Buddhist temples and other construction, furniture, and sculpture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Japanese cypress (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood of the Cryptomeria japonica tree, an evergreen native to eastern Asia. It is reddish brown, soft, fragrant, and used for construction, furniture, and ornamental carving.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Japanese cedar (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Metallic element having symbol Nb and atomic number 41, formerly named columbium; soft grayish-white transition metal used in superconducting alloys.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: niobium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dunne staalplaat bedekt met een laagje tin. De staalplaat wordt verkregen door uitwalsen van blokken in de walserij, wordt vervolgens ontvet, gebeitst en afgespoeld en door een tinbad gehaald. Tin hecht dan zeer goed en vormt een laagje van geringe dikte, dat het overige materiaal beschermt tegen aantasting [...]
Thin, protective coating of tin applied to sheet iron or steel by electroplating or dipping.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: blik
blik (materiaal)
tinplate
witblik

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Water-soluble anionic surfactant used in detergents and other cleaning products such as toothpaste. In conservation, used in the aqueous cleaning of painted surfaces.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium lauryl sulfate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Yellow surface coating of friable material that forms on unprotected realgar exposed to light; this light-induced transformation product is found occasionally in paintings in association with the pigment. In the past, pararealgar has been confused with the pigment orpiment to which this sulfide arsenic mineral is closely related.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pararealgar

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: General term for great variety of chemical compounds formed with flourine.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fluorinated compounds

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Structural sheet of iron or steel, usually galvanized for weather resistance, shaped in alternating ridges and grooves; used as roofing, siding, and the like.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: corrugated iron

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless, solid, water soluble carbonate perhydrate, sodium percarbonate is a highly concentrated source of anhydrous hydrogen peroxide used as a bleaching agent in many applications including paper and textile conservation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium percarbonate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A very hard crust in or on soil formed of sand grains or pebbles glued together by silica; a quartzite.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silcrete

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to the magnesium salt of phytic acid. In conservation, used in a solution to inhibit iron gall corrosion on manuscripts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: magnesium phytate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Repetitive sedimentary rock stratification-formed over the course of a year reflecting seasonal sedimentation variations, usually alternating finer and coarser layers (or ‘varves’) of sand or clay which often exhibit contrasting colors.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: varved clay

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: White hygroscopic crystals, the sodium salt of nitrous acid; used in dye manufacture, as a fixative for color photographs, a meat preservative, and as a corrosion inhibitor when applied to steel.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium nitrite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Insoluble black compound that occurs naturally as galena, the chief ore mineral of lead. It can also be synthesized by reacting a soluble lead salt with hydrogen sulfide or sodium sulfide. When crushed, lead sulfide becomes a powder which is used in photoconductive cells, and as a pigment in ceramic glaze.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lead sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The salt of formic acid, sodium formate is used as a neutral buffering agent. It sometimes appears spontaneously as a layer of white crystalline efflorescence on sodium-rich glass artefacts exposed to the pollutant gas formaldehyde.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium formate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A dark green to black member of the amphibole mineral group, hornblende is common constituent of metamorphic and igneous rocks such as granite, basalt, and schist.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hornblende

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A glassy blue mineral, named for its copper content and its similarity to rivaite, that is a component of the artificial inorganic pigment, Egyptian blue.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cuprorivaite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Concrete mix that can be placed purely by means of its own weight, with little or no vibration.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: self-consolidating concrete

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: White marble with grey/black veins or speckling quarried in Val Venosta, Alto Adige, Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Lasa marble

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Yellow essential oil with a camphor-like odor derived from the dry leaves of various species of eucalyptus tree. This oil is used in medicine, in perfumery, in leather conditioning, and in other applications.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: eucalyptus oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pale yellow, lemon-scented essential oil derived from the tropical lemongrass Cymbopogon nardus, native to South Asia. This oil is used in perfumes, soaps, and insect repellents.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: citronella oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A calcium hydroxide mineral, a member of the brucite group, that is a product of the hydration of portland cement.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: portlandite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Monoclinic crystalline mineral with a combined salt of sodium sulfate and sodium nitrate. Darapskite is found naturally in nitrate ores and in limestone caves. It is more rarely found as a strong saline efflorescence on surfaces of walls and buildings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: darapskite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Artificially produced, radioactive metallic chemical element with symbol Cf and 98 as atomic number. Californium has a few specialized uses as in neutron activation analysis of metals in ancient coins, and in airport security full body scanning.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: californium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Glass created by various techniques but characterized by being uniformly colored as opposed to having a painted surface.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: colored glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: One of three naturally occurring crystalline mineral forms (or polymorphs) of calcium carbonate. The other forms are aragonite and calcite. Spherical precipitates of vaterite have been recognized on microbial mats and biofilms in volcanic substrates as found in Roman catacombs.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vaterite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Ankerite is a carbonate mineral, a member of the dolomite group in which the magnesium is replaced in substantial part by iron, with or without manganese. Ankerite occurs in deposits of iron ore and is also found in thin veins in coal seams.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ankerite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Crystalline sugar, a disaccharide, stored instead of starch in some fungi, algae, and insects. Industrially manufactured trehalose has been used in combination with lactitol as a sugar-alcohol saturation treatment in the conservation of archaeological waterlogged wood.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: trehalose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Blue-green monoclinic crystalline mineral, a hydrated basic phosphate of copper and zinc. Technical examination in 2008 revealed that veszelyite was used as a pigment in mosaic and polychrome masks and funerary offerings from the royal tombs of Calakmul, Mexico.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: veszelyite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A heavy inert noble gas with symbol Xe or X and atomic number of 54, used principally in lamps, lasers, and as a general anaesthetic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: xenon

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gray or black crystalline copper oxide mineral found as earthy masses in copper deposits and as thin metallic scales on lava as at Vesuvius and Etna.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tenorite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Syngenite is a hydrous sulfate of calcium and potassium occurring in tabular crystals. It is sometimes found as a salt deposit on masonry surfaces, a gray-white bloom on walls facing the prevailing wind and rain.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: syngenite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A light, porous, siliceous sedimentary rock composed almost entirely of sponge spicules. Spongolite was much used as a building stone in medieval Bohemia.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: spongolite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to any salt or ester of nitrous acid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nitrite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A compound constituting the essential part of woody cell walls of plants in which cellulose fibril aggregates are embedded in a matrix material consisting of hemicelluloses and lignin. Lignocellulosic biomass is used as fuel and is the feedstock for the paper and pulp industry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lignocellulose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rare metallic element, the penultimate in the lanthanide series, having the symbol Yb and atomic number 70. Ytterbium is a soft, lustrous silver-white metal. Some of its isotopes generate gamma rays when irradiated and are used as a radiation source-substitute for portable X-ray machines.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ytterbium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vulcanite is as an old trade name for a dark, brittle, moldable hard rubber that was produced by heating (‘vulcanizing’) a preparation of india rubber and sulfur. It was marketed in the U.S. as vulcanite and in England as ebonite. Vulcanite was used for small items such as buttons, brooches, and combs, finishes on camera bodies, and for insulation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vulcanite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A carbonate of sodium and aluminum found as a low-temperature hydrothermal mineral in shale. It crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system. It is not mined for ore.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dawsonite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Granito del foro is an igneous rock which was once quarried at Mons Claudianus in Egypt. It is in fact a granodiorite rather than a granite, and is named for its use in buildings of the Roman Forum especially during the reigns of Trajan and Hadrian and in Tetrarchic imperial architecture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: granito del foro

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of several coarse-grained, pale-colored marbles quarried in northern Georgia. White Georgia is used for statuary. The others, such as Georgia Cherokee and Silver Georgia gray, are used as interior and exterior building stones.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Georgia marble

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Monoclinic mineral of the amphibole (double-chain silicate) group. Glaucophane occurs as blue-gray sheets in dense metamorphic rocks such as schists, especially blueschist.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: glaucophane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood from the species Fraxinus floribunda.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Himalayan ash (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rare halide mineral, oxy-chloride of lead, occuring as colorless, transparent striated crystals. Laurionite forms when salt water comes in contact with lead bearing slag, or as an oxidation product in lead ore deposits. The presence of laurionite in some ancient Egyptian cosmetics suggests that the mineral was purposely synthesized by the Egyptians using "wet" chemistry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: laurionite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Porous volcanic stone, a dark reddish pumice, used as a construction and building material in Mexico since prehistoric times.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tezontle

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aromatic gum resin containing a volatile oil that was valued since ancient times in worship, as a medicine, and as an incense resin. It is obtained from the Boswellia sacra trees and others. It contains resins (mostly triterpenoids), gums, volatiles oils (pinene, dipentene), and bassorin. It is usually found in the form of hard yellow grains.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: frankincense (gum resin)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A dark brown or black powder prepared by combining an aqueous solution of silver nitrate and an alkali hydroxide. It is used in silver-oxide batteries, as a laboratory reagent, and as a carbon dioxide scrubber. Salt-free silver oxide showed promise as a bronze disease treatment used at excavation sites but its application has proven a complex and labor consuming method with aesthetically unappealing results.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: silver oxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Grayish white poisonous powder once commonly used as an herbicide and insecticide but retired due to its high toxicity. It is currently used for preservation of color in zoological and botanical specimens; in taxidermy, as ingredient in soap used for cleaning and sterilizing hides.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium arsenite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless, odorless, crystalline salt used in very dilute solutions to fluoridate water and treat tooth decay. In higher concentrations, sodium fluoride is used as a fumigant, and a preservative for zoological specimens, paint, plaster, wood, and masonry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium fluoride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: White, odorless, water-soluble crystalline powder found in almost all laundry soaps. It is a mild alkaline oxidizing agent which serves to increase detergency. It is also used as a deodorant and antiseptic. Dilute compounds of sodium perborate have been used in the conservation field to remove stains from textiles and other materials.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium perborate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Water soluble white crystals or powder used as a disinfectant and bleach. Sodium bisulfite produces sulfur dioxide when heated.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium bisulfite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white crystalline solid, usually encountered as a powder, used as a bleach for wood pulp, and as a versatile reducing agent which converts ketones and aldehydes to the related alcohols.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium borohydride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Granite quarried at Aswan, Egypt with a mineral composition that results in a rose color. It is the type of granite most used in Egyptian architecture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rose granite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Versatile plastic foam used as casting, mounting, packing, and transfer material in applications such as upholstery, thermal insulation, garments, material for sculpture, and in objects conservation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyurethane foam

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A permanent, opaque, synthetic pigment having a pale red or reddish orange color. It is composed of red iron oxide, obtained by either roasting yellow ocher or as a by-product from steel-mill waste. It is used in artists' paints, marine paints, metal primers, and as a filler in rubbers and plastics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: light red (pigment)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Yellow oil derived from the Atlantic Cod and related fishes; a rich source of vitamins A and D used in medicine as a treatment for rickets.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cod-liver oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Nannofossils are microfossils with a diameter less than 50 microns; one micron being equal to one millionth of a meter.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nannofossils

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of the range of synthetically polymerized organic compounds suitable for use in ion exchange.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ion-exchange resin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Yellowish-brown powder that absorbs moisture from the air to form green crystals soluble in water. Copper chloride is used as a fixative in dyeing and printing fabrics, as a wood preservative, and in refining of copper, gold, and silver. The hydrolysis and oxidation of copper chloride is responsible for the destructive formation of bronze disease.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: copper chloride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aragonite is a widespread mineral, a crystalline form of calcium carbonate that is found in deposits formed at low temperatures near the surface of the earth, occurring as stalactites, in sediments, iron-ore deposits, and basic rocks. It is also commonly found in pearls, coral, and shells. It was used in antiquity for beads and other decorative artifacts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aragonite
