owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless hydrocarbon gas, the simplest of the alkynes, also called ethyne. Acetylene burns much more brightly than other gases and was used for stage lighting before electric lights were introduced. It burns with an intensely hot flame and is widely used as a fuel in oxyacetelene welding, soldering, and cutting of metals.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: acetylene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A clear, colorless, poisonous liquid which can be polymerized to form acrylic and modacrylic fibers. It is coplymerized with butadiene to create nitrile rubber. Acrylonitrile is also used as an insecticide.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: acrylonitrile

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Carbonaceous material, especially charcoal, activated by heat at high temperature, or otherwise treated to increase its porosity and adsorptive power. Activated carbon is used in removal of pollutants from gas and liquids and in other purification processes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: activated carbon

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless to white rock-forming mineral, named from the Greek “anhydrous” meaning without water. It is anhydrous calcium hydrate. An evaporate mineral, anhydrite hydrates readily to gypsum.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: anhydrite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Preparation of pyroxylin dissolved in ethanol-ether used in microscopy for embedding specimens.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: celloidin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A natural fine-grained, greenish-blue corrosion product associated with cuprite and atacamite observed on ancient Egyptian bronzes. The formation of chalconatronite seems to have been due to the presence of hydrated sodium carbonates in the arid soils of certain parts of Egypt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: chalconatronite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A thermosetting resin resulting from the carbonization of bituminous coal. It is used as protective coating in many applications, including for marbles and stones.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: coal-tar epoxy

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sulfate of copper, blue crystals in hydrous form, white when dehydrated. Copper sulfate is used as a preservative for wood, leather and paper; as a mordant and dye for textiles; as a biocide, and for a wide range of other purposes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: copper sulfate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A green, calcium magnesium silicate mineral sometimes used as a gemstone; a pyroxene-type mineral with short, monoclinic crystals. The transparent to translucent crystals have either a square or octagonal cross section. The color of diopside crystals ranges from light to dark green. Powdered diopside is used as a matting agent in ceramic glazes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: diopside

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Class of dense metamorphic rocks consisting of red-brown garnet and green pyroxene omphacite; with trace amounts of jadeite, diopside, almandine, pyrope, grossular, and rarely, diamond.
Zeldzaam en zeer hard metamorf gesteente met een mafische samenstelling. Wordt gevormd onder druk die zo hoog is dat ze niet bereikt kan worden in de korst van de aarde. Opvallend qua uiterlijk.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: eclogiet
eclogite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hydrous magnesium sulfate mineral usually found as a crust, efflorescence, or tiny crystals on mine and cave walls. Neutralized and purified, epsomite is sold as epsom salts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: epsomite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A secondary mineral produced by the surface oxidation of primary cobalt. Erythrite is a violet to peach red arsenate once used as a pigment in paints, glass, and ceramics; replaced for these purposes by its synthetic form, cobaltous arsenate.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: erythrite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vitreous green iron silicate mineral, a member of the olivine group, named for the type locality, Fayal Island, Azores. The brittle stone was also produced synthetically as a component of slag separated in smelting at ancient iron working furnaces.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fayalite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil expressed from the seeds of Vitis vinifera grapes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: grape seed oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless corrosive gas, the hydride of fluorine and an extremely powerful halogen acid, hydrogen fluoride is used as a catalyst and a fluorinating agent. Its chief use is in making fluorine-containing refrigerants such as freons. In a conservation context, hydrogen fluoride is considered as an atmospheric pollutant which damages metal structures, and buildings or monuments made of limestone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydrogen fluoride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Transparent, naturally-occurring calcite crystal used in demonstrating the polarization of light. An oblong stone made of Iceland spar found in the wreck of a 16th-century English warship in 2013 has led archaeologists to speculate that the crystal is one and the same as the sunstone, a near-mythical navigational aid said to have been used by Viking mariners.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Iceland spar

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless liquid polymer used as a water-repellent synthetic resin varnish and barrier coating. It is resistant to discoloring, aging, temperature changes, and exposure.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: isobutyl methacrylate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Salt formed by adding hydrochloric acid to lithium. Lithium chloride is the compound used to produce lithium metal by electrolysis. Thanks to its hygroscopic capacity, it is used for controlling relative humidity within a sealed environment. It is also used as a soldering flux, and to produce red colors in pyrotechnics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: lithium chloride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of several silicates containing magnesium; they are generally inert minerals used as fireproofing materials, abrasives, or fillers in paint and paper. The most common hydrated forms of magnesium silicate found in nature are asbestos and talc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: magnesium silicate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Manganite is an oxide ore mineral of manganese that forms dark steel gray to iron black crystal bundles or fibrous masses. A pigment derived from manganite was used in prehistoric cave paintings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: manganite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless, odorless, highly flammable gas, the simplest alkane. Methane occurs in natural gas, as firedamp in coal mines, and is produced by decaying vegetation and in the guts of ruminants. Methane is used as a fuel, and as a starting material in manufacture of chemicals. Methane carried into the stratosphere by rising air acts as a greenhouse gas and degrades the ozone layer.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: methane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A compound in which nitrogen is paired with a more electropositive element, such as silicon, boron, and most metals.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nitride

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless, nonflammable chlorinated hydrocarbon used widely as a dry cleaning solvent and an industrial degreaser.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tetrachloroethylene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rare mineral that occurs as pale yellow crystals. Phosgenite is formed in the oxidation zone of lead ore deposits. Phosgenite has been identified as a constituent in ancient Egyptian cosmetic powders; it appears to have been synthetically produced using “wet” chemistry.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: phosgenite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Radioactive chemical element having symbol Rn and atomic number 86. It is a colorless, odorless, tasteless inert gas. Radon is formed during the natural decay of radium. It is produced in rock and soil and migrates to the surface, sometimes entering buildings through basement walls, resulting in low level exposure. Radon’s health risk is associated with the products of radon decay and not with the gas itself.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: radon

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A starchy powder made from the root of several species of the Orchis genus containing a nutritive starch.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: salep

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A nitrogen-rich, combustible, sludge-like black sedimentary deposit that occurs as a result of the decomposition of microorganisms in anaerobic conditions on the bottoms of lakes and seas. Compressed into hard rock, sapropel becomes oil shale or sapropelic coal.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sapropel

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: One of a group of rock forming minerals composed of silicates of calcium, sodium and aluminum. Marialite, meionite, ekbergite are members of the scapolite group.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: scapolite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Distinctive glass produced on the island of Murano, located off Venice, Italy. Murano was well-known for glassmaking by the 10th century. Even though Murano glassmakers have emigrated elsewhere, experts and commercial markets usually hold that authentic Murano glass is fabricated only in Murano. Most Murano glass is made using the lampworking technique.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Murano glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gelatinous protein that cements silk fibers together in the cocoon. Sericin is secreted along with fibroin by the insect. It is usually removed, by boiling the raw silk in soap and water, during fabric manufacture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sericin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Shape memory alloys are imprinted with a shape so that even after they are deformed, a threshold temperature will bring about a return to the original configuration. Copper-aluminium-nickel, and nickel-titanium are the two main types of shape memory alloy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: shape memory alloy

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless, crystalline compound that forms naturally as caliche in mineral deposits, chiefly in Chile and Peru. Sodium nitrate is used in the manufacture of fertilizers, glass, and explosives.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium nitrate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless or pale yellow unsaturated crystalline hydrocarbon used in dyestuffs and as a fabric brightener.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: stilbene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A yellow colored secondary uranium mineral containing peroxide.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: studtite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of several gaseous compounds of sulfur and oxygen, most importantly sufur dioxide and sulfur trioxide. Sulfur oxides are responsible for about 18 percent of the total average pollutant content of air.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sulfur oxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any salt or ester containing three phosphate groups.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: triphosphate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Chemical element having symbol Y and atomic number 39. Yttrium resembles lanthanide metals very closely and is often classified as a ‘rare earth element.' Yttrium’s most important use is for making the phosphors used in television screen displays and in LEDs. Yttrium phosphors emit a clear red light when excited by electrons.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: yttrium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A mold inhibiting calcium salt used as a food preservative. In conservation, used for reduction of acidity and fungi in aged paper documents.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium propionate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Extremely hard carbide of iron, a synthetic phase in technical iron alloys; in its naturally occurring form it is known as cohenite.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cementite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Carbon dioxide used in its liquid state as a non-toxic, environmentally friendly solvent for cleaning, degreasing, and decontaminating materials. Liquid carbon dioxide is also used to promote plant growth in a greenhouse environment, and, stored under pressure in a tank, as a carbon dioxide fire extinguisher. And has been used in the treatment of ethnological and natural history museum collections.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: liquid carbon dioxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Olive colored magnesium-rich secondary phosphate mineral.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mitridatite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil derived from the seeds of the European Pinus species, especially Pinus pinea. Early written works on painting attest that pine seed oil was used as a drying oil by Spanish painters.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pine seed oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Naturally occurring mineral form of lead dioxide; black crystals or blackish brown masses. In mural paintings, lead-based pigments may convert to plattnerite over time, causing deterioration and blackening to the pictorial surface.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plattnerite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A secondary sulfate mineral found in mine waste.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rozenite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An uncommon copper phosphate mineral found in the oxidized zones of copper deposits in Chile and as a rare mineral in caves. It is also found as a corrosion product on ancient copper alloy objects from Memphis, Egypt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sampleite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pale to emerald green orthorhombic hydrated aluminum phosphate mineral. It is formed by phosphate bearing water reacting with aluminum rich rocks. Variscite is sometimes used in jewelry as a semi-precious stone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: variscite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless or white mineral consisting of potassium chloride, occurring typically as cubic crystals. It is rarer than halite (sodium chloride) and occurs as soft, bitter-tasting, white or grayish, glassy cubes or as masses with halite and gypsum in evaporite deposits in Germany, New Mexico, and Mount Vesuvius.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sylvite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Naturally occuring mineral composed of sodium chloride, usually colorless, cubic crystals. It is found as evaporite deposits in dry lakebeds, near the ocean, or as salt domes underground. Halite deposits occur in Germany, Austria, Russia, France, India, Canada, and the United States.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: halite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sodium chloride that occurs naturally as, or obtained mechanically from, a mineral deposit and sold as large crystals. Rock salt is used to melt ice, as a food preservative, and for the production of soda ash by the glass industry. To refer to the mineral composed of sodium chloride, use "halite."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rock salt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sodium chloride crystals prepared for use as a food seasoning and preservative. Table salt contains sodium chloride with small amounts of a free-flowing agent (calcium silicate or magnesium carbonate), an anti-caking agent (sodium ferrocyanide), an iodizing salt (potassium iodide or sodium iodide), and an iodide stabilizer (sodium carbonate and sodium thiosulfate).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: table salt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Form of sodium chloride, with small amounts of magnesium chloride, magnesium sulfate, and calcium sulfate, that is obtained from the evaporation of salt water; often comprising larger crystals than table salt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sea salt

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Glass that is impenetrable by light, neither transparent nor translucent.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: opaque glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An opaque glass whose red color is generally caused by cuprous oxide crystals.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: opaque red glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A copper sulfate hydrate mineral used historically as a green pigment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: posnjakite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white or steel-gray mineral, iron arsenic sulfide, which occurs in crystalline rock and as the principal ore of arsenic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: arsenopyrite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A rare lead compound, a transparent to pale white mineral in the monoclinic system. It was first identified in the lead-antimony vein at the southwestern end of Bounds Cliff, Cornwall by Cornish mineral collector Richard A. Barstow. It has also been found as a corrosion product on lead artifacts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: barstowite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Calcium stearate is a white, waxy powder, insoluble in water, created by heating calcium oxide and stearic acid. It is used industrially as a water repellent, as in paints and emulsions, and as a food additive.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium stearate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A mineral found as efflorescence on some calcareous specimens and archaeological ceramics stored in oak museum cases. Its name alludes to its components: calcium, chlorine, and acetate.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calclacite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any silicate of calcium as occurs crystallized in diopside and other minerals. Hydrated calcium silicate with inorganic fiber reinforcement is commonly molded into a high temperature insulation material, a safe alternative to asbestos. Calcium silicates are also used in the manufacture of materials such as glass, porcelain, and cement, and as fillers for plastics and paper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium silicate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Transparent to translucent orthorhombic mineral, a member of the baryte group. It is colorless with faint shades of blue (alluded to by its name), red, white and other hues. Celestine occurs mainly in sedimentary rocks, especially dolomites and dolomitic limestones, and is mined for its strontium content.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: celestine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Starch derived from the endosperm of the corn kernel, separated from glutens and fibrous particles by sieving, wet grinding, and wash flotation. Heated with water it forms a viscous medium which thickens into an opaque gel with cooling. Cornstarch is used as a thickener in liquid based foods.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cornstarch

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A mineral consisting of lead chromate that occurs in the oxidized zone of lead mineral veins. It is compositionally identical to the pigment chrome yellow but only secondarily related. The element chromium was found in this rare secondary mineral in 1787 and became the basis for the pigment which was subsequently produced synthetically.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: crocoite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aqueous formaldehyde solution containing 37% by weight of formaldehyde. In conservation it has been used as a fluid preserving medium, and, as an aerosol and fumigant, to treat algae on stone at sites such as the Lascaux caves. Formerly a brand name, now in common usage.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: formalin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dense subsurface soil layer that restricts water flow and root penetration.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fragipan

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Steel coated with a thin layer of zinc to prevent corrosion. The application may be effected by electroplating or spraying the steel with molten zinc, or by coating the heated steel with zinc powder.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: galvanized steel

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The amino sugar derivative of the monosaccharide hexose in which the hydroxyl group is replaced with an amine group.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hexosamine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An igneous rock consisting mainly of the amphibole mineral hornblende.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hornblendite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A marble-like mixed-mineral stone. Its name alludes to its composition: a hydrated magnesium composite.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydromagnesite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A rare, naturally occurring metallic element with symbol In and atomic number 49. Indium is a soft, silver-white metal collected as a residue of zinc-processing operations and chiefly used in the manufacture of semiconductors. Also appears as an impurity in ancient metal objects.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Indium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An amber or brownish yellow-colored hydrous sulfate of iron and potassium found as rhombohedral crystals is sulfurous layers of iron ore.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: jarosite (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Strongly magnetic iron oxide mineral closely related to hematite and sometimes found as a corrosion product on archaeological objects made of iron.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: maghemite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white salt used medicinally as a laxative and anticonvulsant. In conservation science it is encountered as a salt weathering deposit on stone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: magnesium sulfate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Melanterite is hydrated iron sulfate formed after decomposition of pyrite or other iron materials by action of surface waters in mines. It occurs as dull, translucent green crystals on mine walls. Formerly used to make an inky pigment, melanteria.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: melanterite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An alkoxysilane used as a consolidant in treatment of stone and waterlogged wood.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: methyltriethoxysilane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Fossil bone or tooth consisting of the phosphate mineral fluoroapatite colored blue by vivianite. It is used as a gemstone closely resembling turquoise.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: odontolite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An alcohol soluble protein from maize, analogous to gluten, used in making textile fibers, plastics, adhesives, coatings and sizes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: zein

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A mineral consisting of calcium oxalate dihydrate found as tiny white, glassy crystals. Originally found in mud at the bottom of the Weddell sea, Antarctica, which gave the mineral its name. Weddellite, and whewellite form on the surface of carbonaceous minerals in the presence of microbiological organisms such as lichens.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: weddellite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Black, resinous fatty by-product from the kraft paper pulping of pine wood. In addition to being an important source of rosin, tall oil is used in the manufacture of soaps, resins, greases, inks, and other materials.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tall oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of various rocks that are green in color, including altered igneous rocks colored green by feldspar, hornblende, augite, nephrite, or other minerals, or low-grade metamorphic rock containing actinolite, epidote, or albite. Greenstone has been used for carving and construction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: greenstone (rock)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refined, dehydroxylated form of the clay mineral kaolinite. Like other pozzolans, it will chemically react with calcium hydroxide at ordinary temperatures to form compounds possessing cementitious properties; and is used as a substitute for cement in some concrete mixtures.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: metakaolin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A yellow or brown-colored siliceous alteration product resulting from the hydration of basaltic volcanic glass that has undergone rapid chilling. It is found as pyroclastic cones in areas where basaltic eruptions come in contact with water, as in the Galapagos Islands.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: palagonite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Vegetable oil with many culinary uses; also used traditionally as a binder for body paint by Native Americans of Baja California.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pumpkin seed oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oil derived from turmeric (Curcuma longa), a tuberous rhizome of the ginger family.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: turmeric oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white, powdery inorganic compound, the sodium salt of the polyphosphate penta-anion. It is manufactured for use as an emulsifier and chelating agent in water softeners and detergents. In conservation it has been used as a sequestering agent for the treatment of excavated copper and bronze objects, a chelating agent in the conservation of paper objects, and as a surfactant in the cleaning of photographs. It has been suspected of contributing to water pollution.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium tripolyphosphate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Stolzite is a lead tungstate, a rare secondary mineral that is nearly identical in chemical composition to wulfenite with which it is often associated in the oxidized zones of tungsten-bearing lead deposits. It is named for Joseph Alexander Stolz of Bohemia who first identified it.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: stolzite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sodium dehydroacetate is the sodium salt of dehydroacetic acid. It is a preservative and antimicrobial agent that has been used as a food additive and in aqueous deacidification of manuscripts.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium dehydroacetate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Amorphous sodium polyphosphate used as water softener (marketed in powdered form as Calgon T and other copyrighted names), sequestering agent, and corrosion inhibitor. In conservation, sodium hexametaphosphate is used in the cleaning of wood, stone, textiles, and ceramics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium hexametaphosphate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Rare-earth metallic element having symbol Sc and atomic number 21. Scandium is a soft, silvery-white metal which does not tarnish in air. It was discovered in 1879 but predicted a decade earlier and given its initial name, ekaboron.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: scandium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A rare secondary mineral occurring as brownish, yellow or gray prismatic crystals in the oxidized zones of tungsten-bearing hydrothermal base metal deposits.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: raspite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A durable, dense, pink dolerite granite from quarries in and around Porriiño, Galicia, Spain.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Rosa Porriiño granite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A major class of silicate minerals and its members which include about twenty mineral species, among them diopside, rhodonite, jadeite. Pyroxenes are found in many igneous and metamorphic rocks. They are distinguished from the second major class of silicate minerals, amphiboles, by their cleavage planes, characterized by prismatic cleavage at nearly 90 degrees, and a structure of single chains of SiO4 tetrahedra as distinct from amphiboles' double chains.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pyroxene

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A hydrated mineral form of sodium sulfate, the sodium salt of sulfuric acid, occuring in nature as colorless prismatic crystals near salt water springs or lakes, and in caves. Mirabilite is unstable and quickly dehydrates when exposed to dry air, turning into the powder thenardite. It owes its name to Johann Rudolph Glauber who dubbed it “sal mirabile” (“wonderful salt”) when he inadvertently synthesized it while working with sulfuric acid and salt. It is also known as Glauber’s salt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mirabilite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A neutral cellulose derivative, hydroxyethyl cellulose (HEC) is a granular, water-soluble thermoplastic polymer used as an emulsifier, thickener and film former in many types of solutions. It is also used as a sizing material.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydroxyethyl cellulose

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A compound with mineral bonding properties used in aqueous solution for consolidation of mural paintings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: barium aluminate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Non-hydraulic lime is a slower setting low cost alternative to hydraulic lime. Whereas hydraulic lime sets by hydrolysis (chemical reaction with water), non-hydraulic lime, also known as 'air lime', sets by carbonation. It needs air to carbonate and thus set. Unlike hydraulic lime, which is powder derived from lime stone containing impurities, non-hydraulic lime is drawn from pure calcium lime stone and turned into a putty through a process of high temperature heating, slaking, and maturing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: non-hydraulic lime

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Essential oil derived from the rind of the bergamot orange, Citrus bergamia, which is cultivated principally in Calabria, southern Italy. The aromatic oil is used in teas, confectionery, and perfumery.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bergamot oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Limestone formed from pelagic sediment, specifically the ancient ocean bottom layer of soft mud, or “ooze," made from the shells of dead sea creatures belonging to the genus Globigerina. It is the chief building material of the Maltese islands.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Globigerina limestone

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pale yellow, fatty oil made from boiling the shinbones and heels of cattle; used to dress leather and as a lubricant. In conservation, used to restore the elasticity of leather.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: neat's-foot oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Manganese silicate occurring as rose-pink or brownish crystals sometimes used as a gemstone.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rhodonite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A rare brown or black mineral resembling brookite occurring in volcanic rocks as tabular crystals. It has been identified as an element in the yellow slip of Gallo-Roman marbled ware excavated in Graufensenque, France.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pseudobrookite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A colorless, flexible thermoplastic resin produced by the condensation of polyvinyl alcohol with formaldehyde that is used as a structural adhesive. In conservation, plasticized polyvinyl formal film has been used to fill losses in ancient textiles.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinyl formal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A hydrophilic silicone elastomer introduced in the 1970s. It is used in dentistry for dental and gingival impressions.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polyvinyl siloxane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Mondragone marble is a slightly metamorphosed yellow or gray carbonate rock, which was widely employed as monumental stone in the 18th-century royal palaces of Naples and Caserta. Named for Mondragone, Campania where the marble is quarried.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Mondragone marble

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Formerly copyrighted name for a series of alkyd resins used for surface coatings such as varnishes, shellacs and paints. Glyptal is made by heating phthalic anhydride and glycerin together.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Glyptal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Oxygen in its atomic form as it exists at altitudes over 12 miles above Earth's surface. It is the result of photo dissociation of molecular oxygen enabled by the ultraviolet radiation found in space. Atomic oxygen comprises 96% of low Earth orbit atmosphere. In conservation, an atmospheric atomic oxygen beam is effective in removing through oxidation organic materials that are typical of graffiti or other contaminant defacements which may occur to the surfaces of paintings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: atomic oxygen

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A recrystallized limestone composed largely of calcite and brucite; named for a locality near Predazzo, in the Tyrol.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: predazzite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Developed in 1939 at I.G. Farbenindustrie (which marketed it as Perlon), nylon 6 was developed as a dyable, durable nylon fiber intended to compete with DuPont's nylon 6,6. It is very similar but has a lower melting point and a greater affinity for dyes. The two types of polyamide fiber remain the most commonly used by the textile and plastics industries worldwide. It is formed by polymerizing caprolactam under high pressure and is thus also known as polycaprolactam.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nylon 6

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A durable, dyable nylon fiber formed from hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid. Nylon 6,6 was developed at DuPont in 1935. It is very similar in structure to nylon 6, a rival product created ny I.G. Farbenindustrie four years later, and the two types of polyamide fiber remain the most commonly used by the textile and plastics industries worldwide.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nylon 6,6

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Concrete that conforms to a set of standards for high workability, high strength, and high durability established by the Strategic Highway Research Program (SHRP), an infrastructure research initiative authorized by the U.S. Congress.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: high performance concrete

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A super-absorbent polymer, the sodium salt of polyacrylic acid, with broad commercial applications. In a conservation context, it is used as a moisture buffer material for humidity control in museum exhibit cases and in historic structures.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium polyacrylate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An inorganic compound used in the form of a white crystalline powder used variously as an antioxidant, a disinfectant, and a preservative in foods. In a conservation context, it has been used for removing rust stains from paper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium metabisulfite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: White crystalline salt found naturally as mineral alunogenite; made synthetically by treating bauxite with sulfuric acid. It is used as a dye mordant, in tanning, as a flocculant in water purification, and for sizing paper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aluminum sulfate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A soft, aluminum-containing ore; it is an impure mineral that contains hydrous aluminum oxides and aluminum hydroxides. It is named for one location where it was mined, Baux, France, near Arles.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bauxite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Isotopes of the element neodymium.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: neodymium isotopes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A secondary mineral found in the oxidized zones of antimony-bearing lead deposits.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bindheimite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Class of protective proteins, naturally present in the body or produced by the immune system, which target harmful foreign substances, called antigens, in order to remove them from the body.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: antibodies

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A copper arsenic sulfide mineral found in hydrothermal veins and contact metamorphic sites, usually containing some antinomy and grading into closely related mineral tetrahedrite, in which antinomy takes the place of arsenic. It is a minor ore of copper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tennantite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A copper antinomy sulfide mineral found in hydrothermal veins and contact metamorphic sites, usually containing some arsenic and grading into closely related mineral tennantite, in which arsenic takes the place of antinomy. It is a minor ore of copper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tetrahedrite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gum derived from the tree Butea Monosperma native to parts of Southeast Asia and India. Used variously in cooking; as an astringent in medicine; and is valued for its tannin content in leather working.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: butea gum

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A soft, gray or black antimony sulfide mineral; the chief ore of antimony. In powdered form, it was occasionally used as an eye paint in Egypt from the Amarna period onwards.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: stibnite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Variety of andesite produced by now-extinct volcanoes in the Inland Sea area of Japan. It was used during the Paleolithic and Postglacial periods for stone implements.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sanukite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A red, nodular limestone; a Jurassic sedimentary that crops out in the Trento Plateau in the Southern Alps. It is a common building stone in Northern Italy.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rosso ammonitico Veronese

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Calcium hydroxide particles with submicrometric dimensions synthesized by a chemical precipitation process. The nanoparticles dispersed in ethanol have been used as a conservation treatment for consolidating calcareous historic materials damaged by water uptake.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nanolime

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Fluorocarbon elastomer-based synthetic rubber.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fluoro rubber

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An element with atomic number 35 and symbol Br belonging to the halogen family. It is the only nometallic element that is liquid at room temperature. Bromine is extracted from sea water by reaction with chlorine and is used in dyes, fumigants, and other applications.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bromine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Ammonium salt made from a reaction of sulfuric acid and ammonia. It is primarily produced by the destructive distillation of coal. Ammonium sulfate is a commercially important chemical used as a fertilizer, food additive, and tanning agent.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ammonium sulfate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A chemical compound with the property of making silver salts water-soluble. This property was discovered by Sir John Herschel in 1819, who recommended it as a fixer in photographic processing. It is also used in conservation practice as a cleaning agent for silver and silver-gilt surfaces, and removing silver chloride from wet-washed paper and wet-washed textiles.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium thiosulfate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to the gum extracted from perennial grass of the genus Triodia. Australian Aborigines harvest and produce the resin for use as an adhesive.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: spinifex resin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Conglomerate rock composed of alluvial gravels and sands which is found in Lombardy, Italy. Ceppo has been used as building material, as well as for statues and carved decorations, since Roman times.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ceppo

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Finely granulated copper with numerous metallurgical applications produced by various techniques such as electrolysis, atomization, hydroscopy. Each method of manufacture yields a powder with its own inherent characteristics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: copper powder

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic polyester manufactured from corn starch or other renewable resources. First developed for use as a synthetic fiber during World War 2 when organic materials were in short supply. In conservation used as a protective covering for stone materials exposed outdoors.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: polylactic acid

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A group of chemically reactive silane compounds (organofunctional alkoxysilanes) Used in the context of paper conservation to deacidify and strengthen degraded paper.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aminosilane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Any of various preparations made from the seeds, fruits, leaves, or bark of the neem tree, used for medicinal purposes, as an insecticide, and for other purposes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: neem (material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Silicates organically modified by the sol-gel process. In conservation, applied as protective coatings for stone and stained glass.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: organically modified silica

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Reinforced concrete that contains embedded textile material reinforcements instead of the typical metal bars.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: textile-reinforced concrete

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Colorless double salt first prepared in La Rochelle, France, and thus also known as Rochelle salt. It is used as an analytical reagent, as a laxative, and in making mirrors.In conservation science, it is used in saturated solution as a cleaning agent on bronze and other metal objects.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: potassium sodium tartrate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white ore composed of hydrous zinc silicate. It is a minor ore of zinc that occurs in zinc mines worldwide with significant deposits in Siberia, Romania, Sardinia, Slovenia, Belgium, Germany, Poland, England, Mexico, and the United States. Formerly confused with smithsonite, and both were called calamine; see "calamine (mineral admixture)."

Het mineraal hemimorfiet is een gehydrateerd zink-silicaat. Het behoort tot de sorosilicaten. Het mineraal komt met name voor als oxidatieproduct in de bovenlaag van zinkblende afzettingen. Bekende vindplaatsen zijn de Belgisch-Duitse grens, Silezië in Polen, en de staten Pennsylvania en Missouri in de Verenigde Staten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hemimorfiet
hemimorphite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Jarrah is een roodachtige Australische houtsoort (Eucalyptus marginata). Het is sterk, hard en schijnt redelijk brandwerend te zijn. Het is geschikt voor waterbouwkundige toepassingen en werd in Nederland in de 70er jaren ook wel gebruikt als parket
The red-coloured wood of the mahogany gum-tree (Eucalyptus marginata) of West Australia that is strong, hard, reasonably fire-resistant and rot resistant. Known to be used for flooring.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: jarrah (wood)
jarrah-hout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Ancient ivory originating from the tusks of extinct mammoths, usually from individuals that are 10,000 years old or older, but preserved in frozen environments. Mammoth ivory was formerly abundant in Siberia; it was exported to China and Europe from medieval times.
Oud ivoor afkomstig van de slagtanden van uitgestorven mammoeten. Meestal 10.000 jaar of ouder en bewaard ijn bevroren toestand.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: mammoetivoor
mammoth ivory

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Asian wood derived from the genus Palaquium beccarianum. Used variously including the construction of musical instruments, sometimes as a substitute for mahogany wood.
Aziatisch hout, ook wel nyatoh genoemd, uit Guttapercha bomen (genus palaquium beccarianum). Onder andere gebruikt in muziekinstrumenten, soms als vervanger van mahonyhout.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: natohout
nyatoh
nyatoh (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Palmolie is plantaardige olie die hoofdzakelijk wordt gewonnen uit de vruchten van de oliepalm.

Plant oil extracted from the mesocarp of the fruit of some palms, particularly the West African oil palm (Elaeis guineensis). The outer fleshy portion of the fruit is steamed to destroy the lipolytic enzymes and then pressed to recover the palm oil, which is highly coloured from the presence of carotenes. Palm oil is used in making soaps, candles, and lubricating greases and in processing tinplate and coating iron plates.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: palm oil
palmolie

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Bubinga is een harde roodbruine houtsoort uit West-Afrika met een stevige houttekening.

Wood derived from either of two species in the Guibourtia genus of western Africa; it has a light red, brown, or violet background with evenly spaced pink or purple stripes. The wood is of medium texture and polishes to a high gloss. It is used, often as veneer, for cabinets, pianos, other furniture, and for smaller decorative items such as handles and boxes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bubinga (wood)
bubingahout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Fijnkorrelig, sedimentair gesteente dat voor minstens 20% uit fosfaten bestaat. Lijkt qua textuur en structuur op kalksteen.

Formerly, the term referred to a non-crystalline or fibrous form of apatite. In current usage, it is a general term referring to any sedimentary rock containing a high proportion of calcium phosphate.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fosfaatgesteente
fosforiet
phosphorite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Aluminum in the form of thin, flexible sheets or on rolls, used especially for wrapping or covering food.
Zeer dun uitgewalst aluminium, meestal gebruikt als verpakkingsmateriaal voor levensmiddelen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aluminiumfolie
aluminum foil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Architectural glass introduced in the early 20th century used for interior and exterior wall surfaces. Products included glass building blocks, reinforced plate glass, and pigmented structural glass known under such trade names as Carrara Glass, Sani Onyx (or Rox), and Vitrolite. Structural glass was a popular building material of the Art Deco period, and is no longer manufactured.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: structural glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Semisolid fat oil derived from fresh coconuts, often used in the production of cosmetics and candles.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: coconut oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to any of various green to brown silicate glass materials formed when a meteorite impact melts the local rock.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tektite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sulfite having a base that is alkaline. Examples of uses include in a chloride extraction treatment to stabilize corroded marine cast iron, and in wood pulping.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: alkaline sulfite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Among the most important types of rock used for garden building in China. A type of limestone categorized according to its northern and southern varieties, it is found both underwater and in the mountains. The type found in Lake Taihu in Jiangsu province is the most well-known variety, and thus “Taihu rock” has become a general designation for such stones.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Taihu rock

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A salt of sulfurous acid, usually with a qualifying term indicating the base, such as magnesium sulfite, sodium sulfite, or copper sulfite. The sulfites are recognized by their giving off the smell of sulfurous acid when acted on by a stronger acid.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sulfite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sulfur dioxide dissolved in water.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sulfurous acid

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Compounds in which sulfur is bonded to two organic groups.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: organic sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Ionic compounds or salts that contain a negatively charged sulfide ion.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: inorganic sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sulfides that occur when the sulfur atom reacts with organic phosphines.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: phosphine sulfide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The magnesium salt of magnesium sulfite in sulfurous acid appearing as colorless crystals or white, crystalline powder. It oxidizes to sulfate on exposure to air and loses all its water at 200 degrees fahrenheit. It is used as an adsorbent and absorbent, as an agricultural chemical, in the manufacture of paper pulp, as a wastewater treatment, and etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: magnesium sulfite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A soluble sodium salt of sulfurous acid (sulfite), appearing as small crystals or powder. Sodium sulfite is used in multiple industries and exhibits bleaching, reducing, de-sulfurizing, and dechlorinating functions. In the food industry it is used to maintain the appearance of freshness, and to preserve meat. It is also a component in many drugs, to help stabilize and maintain potency. It is used in the pulp and paper industry as a water treatment, and in photography it has been used in developer solutions, and as a hypo clear solution.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: sodium sulfite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sulfite of copper. Uses include in herbicides applied to water to kill plants, but they are toxic to fish and other water animals.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: copper sulfite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Organic compound used variously as a catalyst and also as a consolidant in stone conservation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium alkoxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A white to colorless mineral composed of calcium oxalate monohydrate. Whewellite is formed on the surface of marble and limestone due to the presence of microorganisms, such as lichen. It also occurs in geodes, or septarian nodules; associated with coal measures and surrounding rocks with organic material, and in some uranium deposits. As microscopic crystals in living plant cells and as calculi or as a sediment in the human urinary tract. Named for William Whewell an English naturalist, scientist, and inventor of the system of crystallographic indexing.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: whewellite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Moldable transparent plastic material made of compounds derived or synthesized from biological and/or palaeontological materials. Unlike traditional plastics, which are derived from petroleum, bioplastics are made from renewable resources and are biodegradable.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bioplastics

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de paulownia. Kiri is de japanse naam, meer bepaald voor de paulownia tomentosa. Wordt in China, Korea en Japan gebruikt bij het maken van decoratieve objecten en muziekinstrumenten.
Wood of Paulownia tomentosa, used in China, Korea and Japan to make objects including musical instruments.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Paulownia Tomentosa
kiri (wood)
kirihout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hard, dense, often shiny, mineral composed of zinc carbonate. Smithsonite was the principal source for zinc prior to 1880. It has been found in Greece, Germany, Austria, Poland, Italy, Rhodesia, and the United States. Smithsonite can be white, gray, green, blue, yellow, purple, pink, or brown. It occurs as a secondary mineral in the oxidized zones of hydrothermal ore deposits. Formerly confused with hemimorphite, and both were called calamine; see "calamine(mineral admixture)."
Het mineraal Smithsoniet (of zinkspaat) is een zink-carbonaat Het is ook bekend onder de benamingen galmei en kalamijn. De plaatsnaam La Calamine verwijst naar laatstgenoemde benaming.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: galmei
smithsoniet
smithsonite
zinkspaat

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Dense, dark-colored wood obtained from the Millettia laurentii trees native to tropical regions of Africa.
Wengé is een tropische houtsoort, zeer donker van kleur en met een zeer herkenbaare tekening, nl. een duidelijk patrijspatroon. Het hout is zwaar en hard en dus geschikt voor vloeren en trappen.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: wenge (wood)
wengéhout

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Mineral comprising naturally occuring ferrous phosphate. Vivianite was described after discovery in the St. Agnes mine in Cornwall in 1817. Used in the pigment "blue ocher"; has been found in Roman paint residues. Ferrous phosphate is used as a colorant in ceramics.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vivianite (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Deciduous hardwood from the fast-growing trees of genus Paulownia. It is dimensionally stable and naturally resistant to termites. Paulownia wood has been used traditionally as material for Japanese 'tansu,' footwear, musical instruments, decorative moldings, and as structural elements in building construction.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: paulownia (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A natural admixture mineral of zinc carbonate and hydrous zinc silicate. Because the two ores are very similar and often occur together, the name calamine was given to the mixture but also incorrectly used for the separate minerals. To differentiate the minerals, they were given new names of smithsonite (zinc carbonate) and hemimorphite (hydrous zinc silicate). The name was derived from the place name La Calamine (Kelmis), Belgium.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calamine (natural mineral admixture)
kalamijn
kalamijn (natuurlijke minerale vermenging)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hard, fijnkorrelig afzettingsgesteente bestaande uit de restanten van radiolaria, eencellige organismes die naar de bodem van de oceaan zakken en daar niet oplossen in het zeewater maar dit gesteente doen ontstaan.
Hard, fine-grained siliceous sedimentary rock composed of the remains of radiolarians, single-celled organisms that sink to the seafloor and form this rock, or radiolarian earth.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: radiolariet
radiolarite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Algemene benaming voor de fossielen van sommige tweeschalige weekdieren.
General denomination for the fossils of certain bivalve molluscs. Distinguished from the family of living cockles comprised of over 200 species.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Cardiidae (fossils)
cardium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Chemical element with symbol Ga and atomic number 31. A silvery, soft metallic poor metal, it is used primarily as an agent to make low-melting alloys.
Scheikundig element met symbool Ga en atoomnummer 31. Het is een zilverachtig, zacht hoofdgroepmetaal en wordt voornamelijk gebruikt in het maken van legeringen met een laag smeltpunt.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gallium
gallium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A naturally occurring yellow or greenish glass made of silica found in parts of the Libyan Desert, the Western Desert of west Egypt, and along the Libyan-Egyptian border. Its origins remain a debated issue within the scientific community, but may be the result of a meteor impact fusing desert sand. The glass was used as a gemstone by the ancient Egyptians, and also as a material for paleolithic tools.

Natuurlijk gelig glas opgebouwd uit silica dat gevonden wordt in de Libische woestijn. Over hoe het glas daar terecht is gekomen is er vooralsnog geen consensus in de wetenschappelijke wereld. Het glas werd in de Oudheid gebruikt als edelsteen voor de farao’s.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Libisch glas
Libisch woestijnglas
Libyan desert glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Non-clastic sedimentary rocks with a content of at least 50 percent silicon dioxide, either as quartz or as amorphous silica and cristobalite. Formation is the result of the accumulation of siliceous organic remains. Included are rocks that have formed as chemical precipitates, but not those of detrital or fragmental origin. The most common siliceous rock is chert.
Sedimentair gesteente met silica als hoofdbestanddeel. Het meest voorkomend silicahoudend gesteente is hoornkiezel.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: siliceous rock
siliciumhoudend gesteente

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Term used indiscriminately to refer to soft, low quality copal resins, but particularly the resin obtained from the Hymenaea courbaril trees of South America. The name has also been used for the hard, semi-fossilized, high-quality Zanzibar copal, but anime may be distinguished from other copals by being soft, clear, and alcohol-soluble. There are a number of other oleoresinous products also known as 'anime," or "gum anime."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: anime (gum resin)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A rare, chemically complex carbonate-bearing silicate. Occasionally used in pigments.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aerinite (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An unstable copper trihydroxychloride isomer with a green or blue-green hue. Found in Cornwall, England, Austria, Germany, Greece, and the southwest United States.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: botallackite (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermoplastic polymer that, in its liquid form, consists of monomers of cyanoacrylate molecules. In the form of an acrylic resin it rapidly polymerises in the presence of water; commonly used as a fast-setting, strong adhesive.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cyanoacrylate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Lightweight, laminated panels, typically made with a polystyrene layer between two coated papers. Acid-free foam boards are used for matting and mounting works of art.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: foamboard

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Originally a trademarked name for a hard and polishable plastic material made from albumen from blood or egg white mixed with hardwood sawdust and coloring. The mixture was steam-heated and poured into molds, where it cooled to form a hard, dense, glossy object. Patented by François Charles Lepage in France and England 1855-1856, the invention was later bought by A. Latry, a manufacturer of desk wares such as inkwells and decorative boxes.The material was also used for combs, pipe stems, inkwells, and plaques, and medallions for furniture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bois durci

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A green mineral named in 1801 by D. de Fallizen for the Atacama Desert in Chile. It occurs naturally as copper oxychloride in oxidation zones of copper deposits in North America, Europe, Asia, and Australia, or as chloride corrosion on copper and bronze. The mineral has been used as a pigment on sculpture, manuscripts, maps, and frescoes.

Een groen mineraal, dat deze naam in 1801 ontving van D. de Fallizen. De naam verwijst naar de Atacamawoestijn in Chili. Het komt van nature voor als koperoxychloride in oxidatiezones van koperafzettingen in Noord-Amerika, Europa, Azië en Australië, of als chloridecorrosie op koper en brons. Het mineraal is gebruikt als pigment bij beeldhouwwerken, manuscripten, landkaarten en fresco's.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: atacamiet
atacamiet (mineraal)
atacamite (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A crystalline or granular mineral consisting of a molybdate of lead and ranging in color from orange-yellow to olive green or darker. It can be used as a yellow pigment and in making molybdate red and orange pigments.

Een kristallijn of korrelig mineraal dat uit loodmolybdaat bestaat en in kleur varieert van oranje-geel tot olijfgroen of donkerder. Het kan worden gebruikt als geel pigment en bij het maken van rode en oranje molybdaatpigmenten.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: wulfeniet
wulfeniet (mineraal)
wulfenite (mineral)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Clay used as a medium, typically dried but not intended to be fired. Examples include ancient clay tablets that were inscribed, dried, and then soaked in water for the purpose of reforming and reuse, and some clay surfaces used for wall paintings. For pottery in a state that is not yet fired, but firing is intended, use "greenware." For bricks used as a building material but not fired, use "soft brick" or "sun-dried brick."

Klei gebruikt als medium, vaak gedroogd maar niet met de bedoeling om de klei te bakken. Voorbeelden zijn oude kleitabletten die zijn ingekerfd, gedroogd en vervolgens in water geweekt zodat de klei weer opnieuw kon worden gevormd, en ook soms klei die voor het oppervlak van muurschilderingen werd gebruikt. Gebruik 'groen aardewerk' voor pottenbakkersgoed wanneer het nog niet gebakken is maar dit wel de bedoeling is. Gebruik 'zachte baksteen' of 'leemsteen' voor stenen die als bouwmateriaal worden gebruikt zonder te worden gebakken.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ongebakken klei
unfired clay

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Water dat uit rozen wordt gedistilleerd of rozenessence bevat, gebruikt als parfum, om een kamer een geur te geven, als smaaktoevoeging, in medicijnen en voor andere doeleinden.
Water distilled from roses or scented with essence of roses, used as a perfume, scenting a room, flavoring, in medicinal preparations, or for other purposes.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: rosewater
rozenwater

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An enzyme that catalyzes the dismutation of superoxide into oxygen or hydrogen peroxide. It works as an antioxidant, and has also been used to catalyze the peroxidation of various compounds and as a scavenger of carbon radicals in carbonized silk fabrics.

Een enzym dat de dismutatie van superoxide tot zuurstof of waterstofperoxide katalyseert. Het werkt als antioxidant en is ook wel gebruikt om de peroxidatie van diverse verbindingen te katalyseren en om koolstofradicalen op te ruimen in gecarboniseerde zijdeweefsels.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: superoxide dismutase
superoxidedismutase

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gold or silver. This term was oftern modified with "coztic," yellow, to mean gold, or "iztac," white, to mean silver.
Goud of zilver. Deze term werd vaak gekwalificeerd met 'coztic' (geel), waarmee het 'goud' betekende, of 'iztac' (wit), waarmee het 'zilver' betekende.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: teocuitlatl
teocuitlatl

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Lacquer mixed with powdered cinnabar, applied in thick coats, often carved to produce the traditional red lacquerware in China.
Lak die gemengd is met cinnaber in poedervorm en die in dikke lagen wordt aangebracht, vaak met insnijdingen, om het traditionele rode lakwerk in China te produceren.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: red lacquer
red lacquer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Handelsnaam van een soort thermohardend hars dat door Monsanto wordt geproduceerd.
Trade name of a type of thermosetting resin, manufactured by Monsanto.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Opalon
Opalon (TM)
Opalon (TM)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A hardwood of the species Quercus ilex, or holm oak, an evergreen tree native to the Mediterranean Basin. The trees are often managed as coppice forest, mainly for the production of firewood. Holm oak wood is of light to medium brown color and has a fairly coarse grain. Due to its density and rot resistance it has been used in boatbuilding. The wood is harder and tougher than that of the English oak and the sessile oak, and has a distinctive odor.

Hout van de steeneik, een groenblijvende eik die veel in het Middellandse-Zeegebied groeit. De steeneik levert zeer hard, zwaar hout, in kleine afmetingen, dat azijnhout genoemd wordt. Het leent zich voor onderdelen die zwaar belast worden.De naam is vermoedelijk ontstaan door de zure geur die het hout heeft.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: azijnhout
holm oak (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Een parel die op één plaats aan de binnenzijde van een schelp vastgegroeid heeft vastgezeten.
Pearly excrescence of irregular shape found on the shell of a pearl oyster; may have one flattened side.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: blister pearl
blisterparel

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to very thin hammered or rolled copper sheets (typically about 0.1 micrometers) used for decoration or finishing.
Verwijst naar koper dat tot een zeer geringe dikte (meestal circa 0,1 micrometer) is gehamerd of gewalst en gebruikt voor versiering of afwerking.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: bladkoper
bladkoper (folie)
copper leaf

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Peat excavated by dredging, this is often a mixture of different types of peat, and has a higher efficiency than dry cut peat.
Turf, die door baggeren en niet door vergraven wordt gewonnen. Meestal een mengsel van verschillende veensoorten. Baggerturf heeft een hoger rendement dan gestoken turf.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: baggerturf
dredge peat

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A copper alloy containing copper (89%), aluminum (5%), zinc (5%), and tin (1%).
Een koperlegering met koper (89%), aluminium (5%), zink (5%) en tin (1%).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Nordic gold
Nordic gold

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Hout van de Citrus limon, of citroenboom. Het is fijngenerfd hardhout waarvan kleine gereedschappen of objecten kunnen worden gesneden.
Wood of the Citrus limon, or lemon tree. A hardwood with fine grain that can be carved into small tools or objects.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: citroenboomhout
citroenboomhout (hout)
lemon wood (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Brownish-black crystals or powder, insoluble in water, synthesized by the oxidation of amorphous Cr(OH)3 with oxygen. Developed as rod-like particles for thin film deposition as magnetic recording material, and as a catalyst. Chromium dioxide is no longer widely used because of high production costs and toxicity.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: chromium dioxide

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood of rosewood tree native to China, known for use in good quality furniture from the late Ming and early Qing dynasties.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fragrant rosewood (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A type of glass that will reflect and transmit different wavelengths of light, thus visually appearing as different colors in reflected and transmitted light; that is, the color differs when the light is reflected off the object and shining through the object. Since glass is not crystalline, the dichroic effect is achieved by coating thin layers of various chemicals on the surface of clear glass. Examples of the chemicals are: zinc sulfate, magnesium fluoride, gold, copper, nickel, cobalt oxide, iron oxide, chromic oxide, or titanium dioxide. Examples of dichroic glass objects are those developed by Roman glassmakers, where dichroic glass was prized for its resemblance to natural stones, both in its color and luminescence.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: dichroic glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material comprising the dentin of walrus tusks.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: walrus ivory

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material comprising the dentin of whale teeth.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: whale ivory

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material comprising the bone of whales.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: whale bone (bone)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material derived from the tusks of mature African or Asian elephants.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: elephant ivory

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: General term for chemically reactive silane compounds, used as sealers and consolidants for concrete and sandstones, introduced in the 1980s. They are used alone or in combination with acrylic resins.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: alkoxysilane

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: General term for glass that is not "lead glass," that is not containing a high proportion of lead oxide. Used primarily in cases where the reader may assume lead glass if not otherwise alerted.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: nonlead glass (material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: General term for any glass used as a material that is not "blown glass," that is not shaped by blowing air through a blowpipe into a glob of molten glass. The term is used in situations where it may be assumed that the glass normally would be blown, but is not; also used to refer to glass as a raw material prior to being blown.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: unblown glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Filigree glass having canes that were twisted to form spiral patterns.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vetro a retorti (material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Filigree glass having canes that form parallel lines.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vetro a fili (material)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sheets of film material made of various types of plastic and used for drafting, in use since the 1940s, but emerging as preferred supports from the 1980s through the 2000s. Drafting films will have a matte finish on one or both sides, which gives the surface teeth to accept media or emulsion. Like other translucent supports, drafting film may be used alternately for original drawings or as a reproductive intermediate. Reproductions are typically run through a diazo machine. Stability will largely depend on composition. Acetate was used for drafting film primarily from 1939, with a decrease in usage in the 1960s. Polyester or Mylar (TM) was used from around 1950, becoming very popular after 1970.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: plastic drafting film

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gold found in quartz deposits. As a material, may refer to decorative stones or gemstones comprising quartz having small bits of gold embedded.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: quartz gold

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A nontarnishing alloy typically used for making jewelry, which exhibits the natural color of gold. It is composed of copper (90%), aluminum (7.5%) and gold (2.5%).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Nuremberg gold

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Gold in the form of or reduced to powder or in fine flake form used as a pigment, or for the preparation of coatings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: gold powder

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Exudate of pine trees, used for a variety of purposes, including as a sealant, incense, and in ancient Egypt, for embalming and preserving human bodies.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pine resin

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Copper or one of its alloys in the form of or reduced to powder or in fine flake form used as a pigment, or for the preparation of coatings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: brass powder

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An essential oil obtained from the bulb and stem of the garlic plant. This has many uses, including as a nontoxic biocide against fungal degradation of paper artifacts in conservation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oil of garlic

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An essential oil derived from steaming the leaves of the Australian tea tree. Tea tree oil is believed to have antibacterial properties and is used as a topical treatment for a variety of skin conditions. It is commonly found in skin products including soaps and lotions. In a conservation context it has been used to control fungi, bacteria, and other biodeteriogens on paper objects and in collection care.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: tea tree oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An essential oil derived from plants in the genus Thymus, used variously as a component of medicine, flavoring, perfumes and cosmetics, and in a conservation context it has been used to control fungi, bacteria, and other biodeteriogens on paper objects and in collection care.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: thyme essential oil

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Lightweight composite material consisting of two sheets of aluminum bonded to a core of polyethylene, polyurethane, or other material. This is typically used as milled panels for exterior cladding, interior surface applications, and signage. Aluminum composite material is increasingly used in museum storage and exhibition applications as a non-VOC-emitting material, safe for use around all museum objects. For the panels that aluminum composite material forms, use "aluminum composite panels."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: aluminum composite material

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Variety of shale that contains abundant organic matter, pyrite, and sometimes carbonate nodules or layers and, in some locations, concentrations of copper, nickel, uranium, and vanadium.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: black shale (rock)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Sedimentary conglomerate of calcareous sand and chalk formed in intertidal zones of beaches in tropical and other areas.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: beachrock

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Merknaam van de Duitse firma Bayer-Faser, voor een kunstvezel gemaakt van polyamide-6. In gebruik sinds 1943.
Perlon is a type of polyamide created by the German company Bayer-Faser in the 1940s.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Perlon (R)
Perlon (R)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A silvery-white metallic element of the lanthanide series, atomic no. 60, which was discovered as a component (with praseodymium) of the supposed element didymium and is used in mischmetal and some other alloys.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: neodymium

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Chemical element that, when pure, is a pale-yellow, toxic gas. Fluorine occurs naturally in the form of mineral fluorite, cryolite, and fluorapatite. Fluorine is the most electronegative and reactive element known. Henri Moissan of France received a Nobel Prize for first isolating fluorine in 1886.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fluorine

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Compounds containing calcium.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: calcium compounds

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Acrylic in the form of transparent or translucent solid sheets. Prepared by cast polymerization or extrusion; acrylic sheets are lightweight, tough, and colorless with excellent clarity and outdoor weather resistance. Compared to glass, acrylic is lighter and shatter-resistant, but more susceptible to scratching and transmission of UV. Acrylic has the unique ability to carry light around corners. Originally introduced as 'organic glass' in 1931.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: acrylic sheet

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Glass that is translucent due to having undergone sandblasting or acid etching, producing a pitted surface on one side that scatters the light.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: frosted glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Glass that has an iridescent appearance, usually caused by the application of metallic luster pigments. Examples are the richly colored glasses was first produced in the United States by Louis Comfort Tiffany during the late 1800s.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: luster glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Glass that is coated with a highly reflective metallic coating, often used for mirrors and decorative effects. Glass mirrors with a metallized backing were first constructed in Venice in the 16th century using an amalgam of tinfoil and mercury. In 1836, a German chemist, J. von Liebig, developed a method to coat the glass with a silver salt then reduce it to metallic silver. For glass used to reflect solar radiation in windows, use "reflective glass."
owl:Class.rdfs:label: metallized glass

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Forms of the chemical element oxygen that are different from each other but exist in the same physical state.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: oxygen allotropes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A schistose metamorphic rock containing a high content of magnesium. An example of magnesian schist is serpentine.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: magnesian schist

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A type of composite material consisting of carbon fiber suspended in a polymer. The carbon fiber provides strength, while the polymer acts as cohesive matrix to hold the fibers. CFRP is manufactured as a variety of forms, with various techniques including filament winding, pultrusion, and hand lay-up processes. CFRP materials possess good rigidity, high strength, low density, corrosion resistance, vibration resistance, high ultimate strain, high fatigue resistance, and low thermal conductivity. They are bad conductors of electricity and are non-magnetic.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: carbon reinforced polymer

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Material derived from any of three species of large New Zealand abalone with blue-green inner shell.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: pāua (abalone shell)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Chemical elements of hydrogen having the same atomic number but different mass. Three of them are naturally occuring: 1H (protium), 2H (deuterium), and 3H (tritium).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: hydrogen isotopes

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Pieces of hard, glassy material formed of sand or other sediment fused by lightning; commonly elongated and hollow.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: fulgerites (rock by form)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Wood of the species Dyera costulata. Grows in Malaysia, Borneo, and other regions of Southeast Asia.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: jelutong (wood)

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A mineral that appears as yellowish, brownish, or ruby-red hexagonal crystals, consisting of a lead vanadate and chloride of the opatite group.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: vanadinite

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A cement formulation used to adhere and waterproof stained glass or leaded glass in windows. It consists in a combination of calcium carbonate, Plaster of Paris and boiled linseed oil thinned with mineral turpentine and and colored with lamp black.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: leadlight cement

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Materials comprising parts or components of teeth.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: <tooth components as material>

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Materials comprising parts or components of bone.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: <bone components as materials>
